75TH ANNIVERSARY OF BATTLE OF VIMY RIDGE

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister responsible for the Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, today, Canada is commemorating
the 75th anniversary of the battle of Vimy Ridge, the most important military victory in our history.
Just hours ago, the Prime Minister and the President of France stood before the Vimy Memorial and spoke of the significance of that success.

Mr. Speaker, as your father and three of your uncles were with the Canadian Corps in France, you will certainly know the importance of the Vimy victory reached beyond the battlefields of France and Belgium.
Vimy was the first time all four divisions of the Canadian Corps fought together as a single force. The enemy had held Vimy Ridge against all comers and it would become the graveyard of well over 100,000 allied troops.
Yet, 75 years ago today, the Canadian Corps stormed into the history books. The snow and rain shielding their successful advance was like the weather at home. The tactics were also all Canadian, innovative, well rehearsed, and involving every one from general to private in the battle plan.
The capture of Vimy Ridge changed our nation. Domestically it confirmed that our pioneering people were capable of meeting any challenge. Internationally we were soon more than just a junior partner.
Today 14 veterans of Vimy, ranging in age from 91 to 101, are back at the battleground of their youth. They are being accompanied by veterans who followed in their tradition, the soldiers who took part in the Dieppe raid 50 years ago, where once again Canadians were chosen to lead an allied assault.
Last Sunday I had the honour of meeting our Vimy veterans. At the service at the National War Memorial the rabbi spoke of both the pain and the pride. How right he is. The pain obviously comes from the memory of so many friends, over 3,500 Canadians, who were killed and the bereaved families in need of comforting. The pride comes from the knowledge that they were the peacemakers of their time, the nation-builders of their day.

April 9, 1992
Routine Proceedings
Shortly after the end of the First World War an inscription was placed on a panel in the Peace Tower in this very building. It reads:
They are too near to be great, but our children shall understand
when and how our fate was changed, and by whose hand.
Last Sunday I shook hands with 14 of the men who were there on that Easter Monday in a battle which was described by Brigadier-General Alexander Ross, commander the 28th battalion at Vimy:
It was Canada from Atlantic to Pacific on parade. I thought then
that in those few moments, I witnessed the birth of a nation.

Mr. Speaker, as was stated, 75 years ago, during the few days between the first assault and the time when the guns fell silent at Vimy Ridge, close to 4,000 young Canadians lay dead. History has shown that their sacrifice was not in vain.
We all know that what they accomplished on those cold April mornings was twofold. They captured a prime military objective, one which had earlier defied the efforts of both the French and the British. They also showed, during those few bloody days, that Canadians, working together as a team, were disciplined, motivated and could be counted on to get the job done.
We honour them today, both for the military victory, which helped an ally in a time of need and made Canada, in the words of my hon. colleague, an equal partner.
We honour them for being the first Canadians to go into battle, united as a single force. They were indeed among our nation builders.
We must never forget the lesson of Vimy Ridge. Canadians, working together, can accomplish what others fail to do. Let us not permit the forces, which would divide us, to make a mockery of the sacrifices that those Canadians made when they are called on to do so.
Today, we honour those valiant Canadians still alive from the battle of Vimy Ridge and we also remember those who did not return. Let us honour their memory by making sure that the Canada they fought and died for remains strong, united and free. To do less would be, in the words of the poet, John McCrae, "to break faith with those who die". This we must never do. The greatest memorial we can erect in their memory is a united country.

Mr. Speaker, I rise on behalf of my colleagues to pay tribute to all who fought for Vimy Ridge during more than two years of that war.
Vimy Ridge was a victory others were not able to accomplish. I do not denigrate their efforts; over 100,000 allied troops ended in the graveyard at Vimy Ridge. When Canadians were ordered to try to take it, they were smart enough to spend weeks in planning and preparation.
I remember reading years ago about the kind of planning and preparation that was carried out. One of the most notable was the miles and miles of tunnels that were dug, tunnels that started well to the rear and up to where German lines on Vimy Ridge began.
This made the operation all the more Canadian since hundreds of them who had some experience in this kind of endeavour were assigned to this dirty, wet and miserable task. Mr. Speaker, you will know among the tunnelers were miners from Quebec and northern Ontario and other parts of Canada. They knew what to do and how to do it.
It was the first time Canadians fought together as a unit: four divisions, about 60,000 soldiers. When you add to that the support groups required to ensure success, it had to amount to about 100,000 Canadians directly involved, nursing sisters, medical and first aid staff, thousands in the service corps who spent many weeks of preparation, hauling and stockpiling supplies with horses and trucks and on their backs. In frost and mud, they brought in food, medical supplies and equipment, ammunition of all kinds, clothes, especially socks and boots and there was never enough.
If you put all those contributions together, it added up to a victory equal to, if not greater than, any other in that war. But it was a victory of great cost in lives and suffering; over 3,000 killed and 8,000 wounded, a casualty rate of more than 10 per cent. But one thing we can be thankful for, that if it had not been for the planning and preparation as well as the courage, the casualties would have been much greater and we might not have won.
We honour their memory, and our country must always do so. I believe the best way we can honour all those who took part, and especially those who died or
April 9, 1992

Routine Proceedings
suffered wounds, is to implement and enlarge on the biblical verse: "Blessed are the peacemakers, for they shall inherit the Kingdom of God". Equally blessed is the peacekeeper.
I have always looked upon our peacemaking and peacekeeping efforts as a way to make as sure as we can that the valour of Vimy will not be in vain. For as those very people from both wars will tell you: "No more war, never again."
Our country can, on an ongoing basis, honour and remember great contributions and sacrifices at Vimy Ridge and many other events in two wars by continuing to make every effort at peacemaking and peacekeeping. This is the best way to honour and remember those we honour today, and those from many other battles.

speakerposition: Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
subtopic: OIL AND GAS PRODUCTION AND CONSERVATION ACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, 10 years ago on February 15,1982, 84 Canadians lost their lives in the search for oil in the Atlantic Ocean off Newfoundland.
On that day the Ocean Ranger, one of the most advanced drilling rigs in the world, sank in a matter of hours and there were no survivors.
April 9, 1992

The enormity of that tragedy will be remembered by Canadians for generations to come. Every year in various places, particularly in Newfoundland, family members gather to commemorate February 15, 1982. Most recently on the 10th anniversary that commemoration took place in the foyer of the house of assembly as well as in other locations.
Today we are considering legislation which completes the efforts that began immediately following the sinking to ensure that Canadians are never again put at such risk. Within days of the sinking, a royal commission headed by the Hon. T. Alexander Hickman was jointly established by the Governments of Canada and Newfoundland and Labrador to examine the causes of the accident and to recommend measures to improve the safety of petroleum activity in the Canadian offshore.
At the same time new standards were established by the government for the command of offshore drilling units for structural integrity, for ballasting and maintenance of trim, for the availability of survival suits, and for lifeboat requirements. All rigs operating in Canadian waters were immediately returned to port to ensure that they met these new standards.
In the ensuing months all regulations governing offshore safety were reviewed. New standards were developed for the structural design of rigs, for training, survival equipment, evacuation systems, emergency procedures, contingency plans, weather forecasting, and performance standards for standby vessels as well as rescue craft.
When the royal commission made its final report in 1985, over half its recommendations had already been implemented. Since then all remaining recommendations have been acted on. Canadian safety standards for the offshore are now among the most advanced in the world.
I had opportunity to visit the offshore in the North Sea a few months ago. One cannot help but be impressed by the scope of the projects, by the coming together of men and women of various nations in a tremendous enterprise in the North Sea. For example in the harbour of Aberdeen, Scotland, the joining of a traditional enterprise, namely fishing and the new enterprises of oil and gas, particularly oil discoveries and development in the North Sea, is most apparent.
Government Orders
It is interesting to speak to the people of that area and the manner in which they have been able to reconcile, as I say, a very traditional activity and the new-found wealth of the North Sea.
In Aberdeen today the helicopter traffic is the greatest single helicopter movement in the world other than during military manoeuvres when the world joins together in activities such as the gulf war. The emphasis on safety is unbelievably pervasive in everything they do, all the way from their training when they get their first instruction to the manner in which they wear their survival gear and their suits, to the manner in which they get on to the helicopter systems, to the manner in which they conduct themselves when they are on the rigs and the return.
Despite all that effort just in the last number of weeks there were lives lost in the North Sea in the movement of men and equipment by helicopter.
I think those of us who are responsible for these activities but who have to take advice from those who know safety have attempted in this bill to incorporate the very best procedures, equipment purchasing or procurement we are able to do. We have had the events of the last few weeks to again bring emphasis to the danger that this work naturally is part of daily activity.
The matter of safety never rests. In fact,one can never have the assurance that "everything has been done" because there could always be more that might be done. So often it is bitter experience that teaches or dictates to us what more needs to be done.
We hope that this bill and the regulations that flow from it will give not only more assurance, but will in fact put us even further at that critical edge of where safety, despite the circumstances that we know we face, is not compromised. While most of the Hickman recommendations were addressed by changes to standards and regulations, a small number required a reassessment of the way in which regulatory authority should be exercised, particularly in emergency situations.
To address these recommendations, the government appointed a task force to examine regulatory practices and other offshore jurisdictions. That is why I reference, for example, to the North Sea.

April 9, 1992
Government Orders
The task force concluded that a number of changes should be made to Canada's regulatory system and that these should be embodied in legislation. Following consideration of the task force recommendations by the government, intensive consultations were held for several years with interested parties on the substance of the proposed legislation.
I want to say to you, Madam Speaker and members of the House, these have been intense negotiations. The Coast Guard, other departments, provincial authorities, unions, have been, to say the least, breaking new ground. They have been time-consuming. I accept very much that they have been time-consuming as well.
To complete the process of reforming Canada's offshore safety regime, the government has therefore tabled amendments to the Oil and Gas Production and Conservation Act, which you now have before you for consideration. The act will be re-entitled "The Canada Oil and Gas Operations Act" to better reflect the all-encompassing nature of the act. By virtue of the joint offshore oil and gas management regimes which have been established in Newfoundland and Nova Scotia, consequential amendments will also be made to the East Coast Accord Implementation Act and similar amendments will be made by these provinces to their accord legislation.
The Canada Oil and Gas Operations Act is designed to ensure that an integrated approach is taken to the certification and operation of all equipment used in the exploration for and production of offshore oil and gas resources. Offshore exploration and production units are extremely complex pieces of equipment. They must be capable of meeting all of the risks associated with drilling for and producing oil and gas and, at the same time, they must also be able to meet the might and fury of the worst ocean storms.
It is very interesting as minister of energy to meet with other ministers with that responsibility. One of the questions they constantly ask is: "How are you going to meet the storms in the North Atlantic as you bring your goal production into reality?" I find it rather interesting that often Canadians seem to have less awareness of what is happening and hopefully can continue to happen on the east coast because they relate their own experiences. Whether it is the people of the United Kingdom or the people of the Scandinavian countries, they have great experience and we can learn from them, but they know especially about the particular conditions that we have to face off the east coast of Canada.
On the other hand, just for the interest to the House, despite the difficulties we are having with Hibernia at the present time, Canada's first oil production will come onstream in the next number of weeks, before this place rises for summer, I would hope. Canadians should be aware that these historical events are in fact unfolding off our east coast. Not only must this equipment that we use in these very hostile areas meet these dual challenges, so must the people who operate it. That is perhaps the most important lesson that we have learned from the Ocean Ranger catastrophe. Offshore safety fundamentally depends upon having the best equipment operated with clear, consistent and comprehensive safety procedures, by crews that are thoroughly trained in both oil and gas and marine aspects of their work.
The bill you have before you contains provisions related to these fundamental aspects of offshore safety. In addressing the fundamentals of equipment procedures and training, as well as organization, the bill creates a framework that will enable Canada to maintain a standard of offshore safety as high as any in the world.
For example, the bill requires all operators of exploration and production equipment to obtain a certificate of fitness from an independent certifying authority in order to conduct petroleum activities. The certifying authority will be responsible for ensuring that the equipment meets all safety standards related not only to oil and gas activities, but to marine activities as well.
The certification process will ensure both a comprehensive and integrated approach and is taken to examine the fitness of equipment to work safely in the offshore.
The bill also requires owners and operators to have appropriate operating procedures and trained personnel to carry out offshore petroleum activities safely and to make a formal declaration to this effect. It further requires that at all times one person, the offshore installation manager, be in charge of the entire operation. We want a very clear delineation not only of command procedures but in terms of people who are in charge. To ensure consistency in ongoing improvements
April 9, 1992

in the administration of offshore regulations, the bill provides for the creation of an oil and gas administration advisory council with representation from the federal government and appropriate provincial governments, as well as all regulatory authorities with responsibilities for the safety of petroleum activities on the frontier lands.
It also provides for an offshore oil and gas training and standards advisory board to be established to encourage the development of uniform requirements for training, qualification, accreditation standards and course assessments.
In the case of an emergency where the safety of personnel or equipment could be in danger, the bill provides the minister of energy with the power to suspend temporarily specific sections of other federal acts to ensure that there are clear lines of authority to deal with the emergency situation. There is the right in that comment where I am sure it becomes apparent to you very quickly why there has been much negotiation and debate, not for grabs of authority by the minister of energy or the department of energy. My colleague the Minister of Transport is in the room today. He has responsibilities such as the Coast Guard, the Ministry of Transport. How do we, not only through the government federally, but through the provinces, the unions, the men and women who are working there, the companies, have a co-ordinated plan?
I pointed out already the kind of personnel that is needed in terms of this kind of operation. I believe it is estimated that in the city of Aberdeen, Scotland, alone, something like 23,000 people are involved. We are not working here with a small operation. This is massive and it needs these regulations.
These are some of the more important measures which have been included in the bill before you. It is the product of extensive consultations. Would I have liked to have done it in a shorter period of time? The answer is yes. But I do not apologize for the consultations that took place and the product that we have today. It is not only a product of extensive consultations here within Canada, but internationally. We went to look at international experiences and how we could incorporate those experiences into our new emerging offshore development, off Canada's east coast particularly.
It is based on the insight and experience of foreign regulators and safety inquiries such as that into the Piper
Government Orders
Alpha accident in the North Sea. I had extensive briefings on the Piper Alpha accident. In Canada, federal departments, provincial and territorial governments, knowledgeable experts, offshore regulatory boards in Newfoundland and Nova Scotia and the oil and gas industry have been consulted. I can say that in all important aspects they have had an opportunity to consider the safety measures contained in the bill and bring their accumulated wisdom to bear on it.
In conclusion, one of the great benefits of becoming a member of Parliament is that you find Canadians in all walks of life, different experiences, different backgrounds, ordinary Canadians doing very extraordinary things. I remember as a newly minted Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development being on my first offshore rig off Tuktoyaktuk in 1979. I have been there since. Of course, right at the moment we do not have any development in that area.
I will never forget that. It was a cold day. It was summer, but it was still cold. There was sleet. There were two men working on the drill floor. One was a young man from Hamilton. I asked him how did he get there and why was he there. He had probably as good a reason as I could find. He said: "I'm getting married and I need some money". It made sense to me. That was pretty practical, I thought.
Working beside him was a young Inuit lad. I said: "Why are you here?" He said: "It's my home". That made sense too. I said: "Isn't this going to change your way of life?" He said: "Yes, but we will still try to retain as much of our traditional way of life as possible". That was incorporated in that development in the north. In the mining industry as well that was done.
Both men agreed on one thing despite their different backgrounds. They thought that they were really doing something for Canada. They were going into a hostile area, tough conditions, and what they were doing was exploring. They were at the frontier. Iliey knew it would have meaning for Canada.
On Canada's east coast today, are there problems with Hibernia? The answer is yes. Do I believe sincerely in my mind that someday the offshore of Canada is going to be as important as what I saw in the North Sea, as it has been for Europe? The answer is yes, despite the present difficulties.

April 9, 1992
Government Orders
One thing I know is we can have the best safety regulations, we can have the best equipment, we can have the best knowledge, we can have the best experience, but it is going to be the men and women who are giving of themselves, their expertise and yes, very often, working in conditions that are very dangerous to do this for our country.
I say to my colleagues opposite, if there are improvements we can make to the bill, we will obviously want to consider that. We believe that this bill is only going to be as good as the best advice we can get to have the best safety regulations for the men and women who work in our offshore.
May I just say to the House I will be able to stay for a while to listen to my colleague from Edmonton Southeast. If I leave at eleven o'clock, then my colleague, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development, the member for St. John's East, who comes from Newfoundland, will be representing the government during the rest of that debate.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my colleague, the member for Gander-Grand Falls, wanted very much to be here to speak in this debate on behalf of my party this morning. We had talked about it. He had prepared. As those opposite know, this is the morning of the National Prayer Breakfast and he is one of two people who are acting as co-chairmen of the seminar for approximately 150 people, I believe, from across Canada. It was simply impossible for him to be here and there simultaneously. He and I both very much regret that the bill is going ahead now rather than at some other time when the member for Gander-Grand Falls could have been here to speak on it.
My colleague from Bonavista-Trinity-Conception will be speaking and giving the Newfoundland perspective later in the day.
First, I would like to read the surnames of the victims of the tragedy which precipitated what we are talking about today. Those from Newfoundland, their surnames are: Arsenault, Augot, Baldwin, Blackmore, Boutcher, Brinston, Buriy, Bursey, Caines, Chafe, Chalmers, Clarke, Conway, Crawford, Dawe, Drake, Dwyer, Dyke,
Escott, Evoy, Fenez, Foley, Freid, Fry, Greene, Harnum, Heffeman, Hickey, Hicks, Holden, Howell, LeDrew, LeDrew, Maurice, Melendy, Miller, Noseworthy, O'Brien, O'Neill, Palmer, Parsons, Pieroway, Pinhom, Power, Putt, Reid, Sheppard, Smit, Smith, Stapleton, Tiller, Tilley, Warford, Winsor and Winsor.
The victims from outside Newfoundland, their surnames are: Blevins, Dagg, Dodd, Donlon, Droddy, Dugas, Fogg, Ferguson, Garbeau, Gorum, Grandy, Halliday, Hatfield, Hauss, Howell, Howland, Jacobsen, Kuhl, Madden, Mitchell, Morrison, Powell, Rathbun, Ryann, Smith, Thompson, Vaughn, Watkin and Wilson.
I would say at the outset it is most regrettable that this tragedy took place ten years ago.
The final report by the Hickman royal commission was handed to the government in 1985.1 appreciate that this minister has not been the minister since 1985. It is unfortunate that it takes this long to bring forward this bill. It strikes me as something that is basically unforgivable to the seriousness of the issue and to the tragedy of the people whose names I just read and their families.
Having been a federal public official in the justice department, I know that consultations can take time. But ten years is not needed if there is any ministerial or successive ministerial will to employ with all deliberate speed. As the minister said, the stakeholders had to be consulted, but does it really take approximately 3,650 days to win concurrence for this bill from the stakeholders?
Ten years ago in the Basilica of St. John's, Newfoundland, Archbishop A.L. Penny addressed about 2,000 friends, co-workers and family members of the victims of the Ocean Ranger disaster and he asked: "What makes this tragedy so benumbing? This disaster has its own special desolation because it is associated with a venture which was bright with promise", he said in response.
Promise there was on this "largest, safest, unsinkable, most advanced semi-submersible in the world" as the tour guides used to describe the rig. Among those in the petroleum industry it was referred to as the Cadillac of the oil rigs. I suppose now they would say Mercedes or some good Japanese car.
April 9, 1992

However, since February 15, 1982, there has been significant change in the way those marvels of modem technology are perceived by Newfoundlanders and all other Canadians.
The safety concerns voiced by some Ocean Ranger crew members who referred to the rig as the "Ocean Danger" rather than the "Cadillac of rigs" suddenly came into sharp focus. As it turned out the rig was a disaster waiting to happen. No one could answer troubling questions about why the supposedly unsinkable rig had gone down and why not a single crew member had survived.
Testimony before the Hickman commission suggested lax federal regulations and industry standards at the time made the tragedy all but inevitable.
Several issues have been addressed by a royal commission whose final report made a great many recommendations on marine drilling practices on the offshore of Atlantic Canada. In its 1986 "Response to the Recommendations of the Royal Commission on the Ocean Ranger Marine Disaster", the Mulroney government committed itself in recommendation 107 to establish "without delay performance standards and initiate a joint major engineering development project to produce a safe primary evacuation system for offshore drilling rigs".
According to some sources, a decade after the tragic loss of the Ocean Ranger and seven years after a royal commission investigating the tragedy released its report, offshore evacuation systems have still not been established. Inquiries to the federal government as to how performance standards would be implemented were met by the explanation that energy, mines and resources department had other priorities.
The royal commission said the lifeboats on the Ocean Ranger were inadequate. According to the spokesman for the Canada-Newfoundland Offshore Petroleum Board, such lifeboats are now rigorously inspected and each rig must have enough to carry twice the crew actually on the rig.
What appears to remain unresolved is whether even with the best training and equipment available offshore rig employees in small lifeboats have a decent reasonable chance of surviving in the mountainous seas, if the boats can be launched at all. Are the evacuation systems designed and capable of launching a lifeboat from a rig
Government Orders
far away from the structure in order to avoid collisions with its foundering legs?
It is believed that just such a collision damaged and caused the sinking of the only lifeboat known to have been launched from the Ocean Ranger, and with scores of lives lost.
According to Norwegian authorities, and they have much experience in offshore matters: "Launching lifeboats from any vessel in 80 knot winds and 50 foot seas is next to impossible. There really is no technology to do it safely". New evacuation procedures being used in the North Sea are far better than those used in Canada, I understand.
For example, soon after the capsizing near Norway of the U.S. leased Alexander L. Kielland in 1980 the Norwegians quickly implemented a requirement that their rigs must be upgraded to withstand both the loss of one supporting leg and a list of 35 degrees without toppling over. The Ocean Ranger was abandoned after it developed a list of 15 degrees.
The Norwegians have also tested a new launching system which allows lifeboats to slide down a ramp and fall freely into the water.
Do the new measures seriously intend to address the issue of emergency evacuation of oil rigs, I would ask the minister? Do we take foreign technological advances into consideration? Or do we choose to remain ignorant of technology that elsewhere races ahead of us?
Families of the crew members who perished in the 1982 disaster have been lobbying hard for new legislation and are demanding an end to winter drilling. But this government unfortunately has failed to address the issue completely. It has not become a priority because as a result of depressed oil prices it would appear that only a few rigs have been working in Canadian waters in recent years.
In its shortsightedness the government does not appear to realize that the situation is likely to change if major production projects such as Hibernia go ahead, and we all hope they do. In fact, plans for further development of Terra Nova are already in place.
Undoubtedly all parties involved would like to know whether this new legislation is comprehensive enough to ensure that the reasonable safety of these new rigs would not be shunted into second place again, especially as oil exploration is pushed into deeper and more unpredictable waters.

April 9, 1992
Government Orders
The Ocean Ranger Foundation, established shortly after the tragedy to assist families of the crew members unfortunately folded in December 1985 for lack of funding. That organization asked federal and provincial governments for $75,000 but the two levels of government responded with $5,000 from each. While the foundation was formed to assist the families, its prime concern was with the safety of those working offshore.
As one of its members put it: "The government wants the disaster and the foundation to fade away like a bad dream. They are unwilling to go on funding us because they know that we will continue to look over their shoulders. Yet, in announcing their withdrawal of support, they do not have the good graces or the guts to put the arguments on the table".
Many employees and families brought their concerns about safety to the foundation and with its role as a watch-dog over offshore safety gone there seems to be a large void to fill.
The federal government, either this one or the next one, should fully accept responsibility for ensuring that offshore safety measures are adequate.
In April 1986, the then Minister of Justice, who is now the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans, vowed that the report of the royal commission on the Ocean Ranger marine disaster "was not going to be buried or gather dust on any shelves". Indeed it has not been buried for good, yet 10 years and millions of dollars later, this government, buried deep in its red tape is not capable of passing legislation before the 10th anniversary of the Ocean Ranger sinking. Maybe the minister can tell us why it has taken 10 years to do it.
In closing, it essentially amounts to blatant insensitivity to the victims' families, to the people of Newfoundland, people in the oil industry across Canada including Alberta, and to Canadians as a whole. It is also a shame for this minister and his officials. I say that recognizing that he has not been the minister for 10 years. I fully acknowledge that.
We on this side will endorse the new measures if working on oil rigs in the North Atlantic is made safer today than was the case when 84 men died or froze to death in stark and lonely moments of terror.

subtopic: OIL AND GAS PRODUCTION AND CONSERVATION ACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, we are dealing with Bill C-58 before us, an act to amend the Oil and Gas Production and Conservation Act and other acts in consequence thereof, presented today for second reading by the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources.
I thought it rather fitting to comment that at the beginning of today's session we were commemorating lives lost and victories won in fields even further afield than the Canadian offshore when we heard a number of members and the associate minister of National Defence pay tribute to those who fought at Vimy Ridge. It is the 75th anniversary of that battle in which so many Canadian lives were lost. This August will be the 50th anniversary of the Canadian raid on Dieppe when again many Canadian lives were lost.
April 28 has officially been recognized by this House as a day of mourning for those Canadians who have lost their lives and have been injured in the workplaces of Canada.
With all those events coming into place this year which is the 10th anniversary of that horrible incident that took place off the Canadian east coast on February 15,1982, it perhaps helps to put into context just what a price many Canadians pay for the standard of living we enjoy, and that we may enhance our standards and improve our production capabilities in order to provide even better standards for those who will come after us.
On February 15, 1982 during a severe Atlantic storm, the semi-submersible drilling unit, the Ocean Ranger, which was the largest of its kind in the world at the time, capsized and sank about 166 nautical miles east of St. John's, Newfoundland. All 84 men on board perished.
While the Ocean Ranger was regarded as the Cadillac of offshore rigs at the time, it was certainly not the first in the world. While it involved the second largest loss of life in this type of incident in world history, it was not the first serious accident. There had been others. Work on offshore oil rigs around the world had resulted in 241 lives lost in various types of accidents before the Ocean Ranger disaster occurred.
April 9, 1992

The worst of those accidents involved the collapse of a floating hotel in the North Sea off the coast of Norway in March 1980 in which 123 workers were killed. The second worst, the collapse during a storm of an oil rig in the Bohai Gulf off north-east China in November 1979 left 72 workers dead.
In October 1980, a blow-out killed 18 workmen aboard the U.S.-owned rig Tappmeyer off Saudi Arabia. In April 1971, 13 were drowned when the U.S. rig Ocean Express sank off Texas. In December 1965, the British rig Sea Gem collapsed in the North Sea with the loss of 13 lives. In May 1979, a platform collapsed aboard the U.S. rig Ranger I in the Gulf of Mexico, killing two workmen. The Tappmeyer incident off Saudi Arabia in October 1980 resulted in many more casualties.
It is just a little over 10 years since the disastrous incident involving the Ocean Ranger occurred off our east shore. My colleague from the Liberal Party, the member for Edmonton Southeast, appropriately read into the record today a list of the surnames of those who perished in that disaster.
Perhaps it would be good for Canadians to think back and remember the tragic and horrible headlines that dominated all of the Canadian news media at that time. There were 84 very personal family stories of the impact of that disaster. It was caused by the absence of proper diligence being paid to the situations that arise on high seas in stormy conditions, when we venture into the kind of major innovations in technology required by offshore oil drilling.
The day after the disaster, the then Leader of the Opposition, who is now the minister responsible for the constitutional negotiations, rose in his place and said the Prime Minister should "immediately designate" one federal ministry as the lead agency in rescue efforts.
A little over 10 years have passed and the member who raised that point then is now a senior member of the government and a former Prime Minister. We are finally designating one senior minister to be responsible for these types of affairs.
My colleagues, many people in the industry and I are not sure, however, that the minister of energy-it is no criticism of the existing minister-who is primarily responsible for production and revenue for oil and gas is the appropriate minister to have the ministerial override in matters dealing with safety on the high seas.
Government Orders
Later on in this debate, my colleague, the member for Thunder Bay-Atikokan, will be dealing with that particular point in somewhat more detail and with more emphasis.
The Minister of Transport is much more directly responsible for and familiar with matters relating to safety and proper conditions of operations on the high seas. Perhaps when it comes to emergency designations in the area of safety, he should be the minister who has the override in disaster situations.
The minister stated there had been a lot of consultation, and I am sure he is correct to some degree. In fact one of the reasons given for the 10-year plus a few days delay in having this bill come before the House was all the extensive consultations that took place.
Certainly we agree those consultations were necessary, particularly on matters relating to safety, where we have had such clear burning images in our minds of what the lack of proper safety enforcement and provisions can mean.
However, I took the opportunity a while ago of asking the minister of energy just what consultations with certain parties had taken place regarding this bill. A letter dated March 19 was sent to my assistant from the minister's senior adviser on energy in answer to the question whether there were any consultations with trade unions, particularly the Seamen's International Union. I would point out as an aside it is the union most involved in Canadian shipping and in the type of rigs we are dealing with here today. The answer was that there were no formal consultations with trade unions.
It goes on to add the bill does not conflict with worker safety requirements vis-a-vis regulations under the labour code.
I should point out, to be fair, that in the development of the oil and gas occupational health and safety regulations under the labour code, there were extensive consultations with labour.
Despite that, in regard to this bill, there are the matters of the ministerial override, the appointment of the safety officer and his duties, which ministry should be involved and which minister has the experience to deal with the problems. It is inconceivable to me and my colleagues in the New Democratic Party, as well as many other Canadians, that in the 10 years of consultations leading up to the presentation of this bill before this

April 9, 1992
Government Orders
House of Commons, the one union that had the primary responsibility of representing those people who died and representing the direct interests and life, health, and safety of those who will be working and do work in this industry in the off-shore was not consulted. I find that incomprehensible and inconceivable.
I would like to briefly quote from a letter sent to me from Mr. Roman Gralewicz, the president of the Seafarers' International Union of Canada, dated April 2. He says: "This attempt by the Department of Energy, Mines and Resources to go through a legislative back door with safety legislation without the input of labour, regardless of its content, shows the blatant disregard this government and the oil industry truly have with respect to fair representation of the industry work force. This designated attempt by energy, mines and resources to usurp the mandate of Labour Canada, a federal department which does utilize the consultative process with its clientele and is responsible for occupational safety and health, warrants investigation. Why were labour representatives not invited to participate? What are the government and the oil industry hiding? As employee safety is an issue, is EMR the right department to responsibly handle it?"
We will be supporting this bill in principle. We want it to go before committee, but before we enter into detailed clause by clause study, I hope we will have a significant opportunity to be able to have representatives of the people who died and of the people who put their lives at risk in these kinds of operations before that committee. Then we can have the kind of consultation that should have been carried out in the formation of the legislation.
The government may believe it has consulted, as it did in previous regulations, but it apparently did not consult with organized labour in putting together the legislation now before us. I find that lack of tripartite consultation rather incomprehensible. This ministry ignored what should have been an automatic process in matters dealing with health and safety. That makes me and many others question whether this ministry is the appropriate
one to have an override in matters dealing with dangerous situations, safety and health. It just seems wrong.
In all jurisdictions across Canada, both federal under the Canada Labour Code and provincial, in matters dealing with health and safety, everything is done on a tripartite basis. When it comes to health and safety, many labour relations boards are structured in the same way. They have direct ongoing representation from the three parties, government or government agencies, labour, the working people involved, and management of the industry concerned. They are all involved in health and safety decisions. There can be no other way. The lack of sensitivity and understanding of this ministry to that very essential principle is what makes me very, very concerned about the direction the ministerial override in this legislation has taken.
As we go through the bill, I just want to touch on a couple of other items. I have had a number of consultations on this bill with the leader of the New Democratic Party in the province of Newfoundland. Mr. Newhook initially built his involvement in public affairs largely around working with the families of those who died in this disaster. That was one of his earlier main contributions and the beginning of his public life in the province of Newfoundland. He has built up considerable expertise in that area and has followed it closely ever since that time.
In a recent letter to me Mr. Newhook said after looking through the legislation and reading a significant amount of material on it:
From what I can gather, the bill coming before Parliament represents what the people in Canada-Newfoundland Offshore Petroleum Board referred to as the last tidying up of the royal commission findings on the Ocean Ranger.
That is correct. Mr. Newhook goes on to say he recalls that Pat Carney set up the Harrison task force to review how government could best deal with the commission recommendations. It was his understanding that the main thrust of the bill comes straight out of that Harrison report. It deals mostly with training and safety. Most importantly, it provides for the separation of a chief safety officer from the chief conservation officer. This is to ensure that safety is separated from other functions within the energy field.
April 9, 1992

He goes on to agree that this is what needs to be done in order to clean up the remaining recommendations that arose from that disaster. The major criticism, Mr. Newhook goes on, of what government has done re the commission relates to section 107 of the commission recommendation. Just to read it briefly, 107 says:
It is recommended that (a) government and industry, without delay establish performance standards and initiate a joint major engineering development project to produce a safe primary evacuation system for offshore drilling rigs.
(b) during the intervening period, it be a condition of the right to drill that existing primary evacuation systems be improved or replaced so as to improve materially their capability to evacuate the crew.
Mr. Newhook, who has been close to the situation ever since the disaster occurred, points out that nothing substantial has been done by either level of government about that critical issue. The industry has put some R and D money into a modified version of davit launched lifeboat systems called PROD. Husky-Bow Valley was the main player in this development. He goes on to say that opinions may vary somewhat as to its usefulness but few would claim that it solves the problem. The bottom line is that we still do not have any effective way of safely evacuating workers from offshore installations in an emergency situation.
He concludes with what I think is a very salient point in terms of our priorities as a country: "Canada is spending billions on space technology and it is ridiculous that we can retrieve people from space but not from our oceans". That applies not only to Canada but to every other major nation involved in offshore drilling. We do not seem to have our priorities right when it comes to the lives, health and safety of Canadian workers in this industry.
While I and my colleagues hope that this bill will move toward that end, and we will certainly do our part along with other hon. members in ensuring that it does, we do call into question again the lack of direct consultation with the representatives of those who died and those who work in this industry in the putting together of this legislation, this wrap-up legislation, we hope.
We also question the decision to have the ministerial override. We agree it is essential that one ministry ultimately be responsible in high risk and dangerous situations, but we question seriously whether the ministry of energy is the appropriate department for that to take place.
We look forward to the committee and dealing clause
Government Orders
by clause with this legislation. We hope that we will be afforded every opportunity to have the appropriate witnesses come before us so that we can take steps to ensure that nothing of this kind, no disaster of this magnitude and consequence, ever occurs in Canada again.

Madam Speaker, I wish to put a question to my colleague who has just spoken on this bill.
It has been a very long time coming, given that it is 10 years since the Ocean Ranger disaster. It is six or seven years since the first preliminary report of the Hickman royal commission into the Ocean Ranger disaster. It is five and a half years since the government gave its initial response to the recommendations contained in the Hickman royal commission into the Ocean Ranger disaster.
Because so much time has gone by I suspect many members who are in the House today have very little knowledge of the debate into the reasons for the Ocean Ranger disaster and those who were here 10 years ago, certainly their memories about the details of this disaster have faded because the recommendations and the changes to the appropriate legislation have been so long in coming.
One of the major recommendations of the Hickman royal commission, one of the major areas of controversy at the time of the sinking of this so-called unsinkable vessel, was the fact that oil and gas rigs were treated in a different manner from all other forms of shipping plying the waters of the North Atlantic. An oil and gas rig or semi-submersible rig was treated as a mechanism for extracting oil or exploring for oil and all other self-propelled vehicles on the surface of the ocean were treated as ships and therefore were subject to the regulations of the Canada Shipping Act. The act therefore required that all of these stringent safety regulations of the Canada Shipping Act be met and that all of the requirements for proper licensing, for a proper captain aboard, be met. In fact we discovered much to everybody's great sadness at the time of this disaster that the same was not true of rigs, that a rig was not considered a ship, it did not require a seagoing captain. The man in charge was an expert in extracting or drilling for oil, but he was not a mariner.

April 9, 1992
Government Orders
So 10 years ago, nine years ago, eight years ago, seven years ago there was a veiy large and strong consensus that we had to move immediately to treat these exploration vehicles, these oil extraction vehicles, like ships. The same kind of stringent safety code ought to apply, the same level of expertise for navigation ought to be available. It was a requirement. It was most important that a single agency ought to be in charge of the regulation regime with respect to these pieces of equipment.
I want to ask my hon. friend who just spoke very knowledgeably about this bill whether he is satisfied that we now have a single agency in charge of safety on oil and gas rigs as a consequence of the amendments brought in today.
I must confess I did a very quick reading of the bill. I note that there is still provision for the minister of energy to set regulations in some circumstances. There is still provision for the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development to set regulations in other circumstances. No doubt, I suppose in some circumstances depending on the nature of the rig, we may still have the Minister of Transport or other ministries involved in the operation of these rigs.
I have to ask myself, 10 years after the tragic disaster that nobody survived on the unsinkable Ocean Ranger, have we finally got it right? Do we have a set of regulations and a regime that we can trust?

I note that the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources has said: "These amendments will close the chapter on the Ocean Ranger royal commission's recommendations". No. Was there anything in the announcement today in closing the chapter on the Ocean Ranger that talked about increasing search and rescue surveillance from the air? No, there was not a thing.

The hon. member said a moment ago that some of our memories are fading as to the exact description of what happened, but I can recall quite vividly reading the testimony of the people who were out there and who saw the men on the water but could not get them they were almost touching them but could not get them. There was no way to take them from the life-rafts on to the ship. They were representing the people of Canada. There was no way. They just could not be taken from the ocean and put aboard the ship in those high seas in those circumstances.
Where is the reference to coast guard vessels? Where is the reference to vessels on the high seas from the Canadian coast guard from the Newfoundland region? None. Yet one of the chief recommendations of the commission was to have some means of saving people in those circumstances on the high seas. What are we left with? I will tell you what we are left with. Government Orders
big as the sister regions up in Quebec and down into the maritimes. No, it is not.

As my colleagues have just spoken about, this bill gives primacy to the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources in matters of safety of events at sea.
When we had the commissioner of the Canadian Coast Guard before the transport committee this week I raised the question of this conflict, of why the minister of energy is given the decision-making power to decide when to abrogate safety laws or transport laws or navigation laws or any other kind of laws that may be appropriately reconsidered in the time of emergency.
The argument from the commissioner was okay. They had worked it out and he was satisfied that the minister of energy had greater knowledge and understanding of issues at sea than the Coast Guard did. That is my interpretation of his words, but I would say to the Minister of Transport he has lost the turf war once again.
In the same way that the Department of National Defence reigns supreme over search and rescue instead of the Department of Transport just because it has the bigger toys is another indication that the Minister of Transport has been captured by other departments.
I believe that the Minister of Transport should be the sole minister designated in this legislation because he and the people who work for him on behalf of the people of Canada have the expertise. They know the sea. They know the air. They have the responsibility for ships and for ship safety. Quite frankly a drill rig is a ship with legs as far as I am concerned, and from time to time it is a ship. There is no question in my mind that the Minister of Transport should be the one who has to make that decision.
The legislation suggested he will be consulted. I can just see the phone call: "John, this is Jake. I need to turn off some lights on the rig because we might have an explosion. What do you think?" Give me a break.
The Minister of Transport has the responsibility in other legislation, in marine matters, for the safety of the rig, for the safety-this is the most important part-of the people who work on that rig, or on that ship, or on that airplane, as long as it is either Canadian or in Canadian waters.
To say that the minister who has responsibility for the economic matters as to the appropriateness of drilling in a particular spot suggests that we have allowed the banker once again to be in charge of safety as opposed to the minister who has that responsibility.
This is not new. We have done battle in this House over this issue ever since the Ocean Ranger disaster, ever since the report came out and the government acted on some of the recommendations.
I know that my colleague, the member for Kootenay West-Revelstoke, will pursue this matter in committee as I did with the minister of energy's parliamentary assistant when he briefed us on the bill. I made it very clear that I was dissatisfied with the designation of the minister of energy in this bill. I know that my colleague will pursue this matter in committee, because we need to put the responsibility where it belongs.
I want to move on and touch on a couple of other issues that are interrelated. The briefing note that was provided to me by the parliamentary secretary on
April 9, 1992

amendments to the Oil and Gas Production and Conservation Act has a line in it that says:
Extensive consultations with accord provinces, territorial governments, industry, offshore boards and other federal departments, including the Department of Transport, and allowing all stakeholders now concur with legislation.
The one set of stakeholders who were not even consulted were the people who represent the workers. In a letter back to my colleague, the member for Kootenay West-Revelstoke, a senior adviser to the minister of energy wrote, in answer to the following question: Were there any consultations with the trade unions, particularly SIU? The answer was that no, there were no formal consultations with trade unions.
This bill does not conflict with worker safety requirements vis-a-vis regulations under the Labour Code. Through the work of my colleague we began discussions with the unions to let them know about the bill and to see what the reaction was.
I have a letter from Roman Gralewicz who is the president of the Seafarers International Union:
This scoundrel attempt by the Department of Energy, Mines and Resources to go through a legislative back door with its safety legislation without the input of labour regardless of its content shows the blatant disregard this government and the oil industry truly have with respect to fair representation of the industry work force.
This designated attempt by EMR to usurp the mandate of Labour Canada, a federal department, which does utilize the consultative process with its clientele and is responsible for occupational safety and health warrants investigation. Why were labour representatives not invited to participate? What are the government and the oil industry hiding? As employee safety is an issue is Energy, Mines and Resources the right department to responsibly handle it?
This bill should be referred to a committee consisting of labour, management and government representatives for review.
That is the view of the president of the Seafarers International Union. He is concerned because those who represent the workers were not consulted.
Perhaps if they were consulted they might say the Minister of Transport should be the lead minister. They might say the Minister of Labour should be the lead minister, but I know they would say it should not be the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources.
The third area I want to touch on is the whole question of the safety of the workers in the event of an emergency. One of the key recommendations that came out of the Royal commission on the Ocean Ranger is article 107
Government Orders
that "(a) government and industry without delay establish performance standards and initiate a joint major engineering development project to produce a safe, primary evacuation system for offshore drilling rigs and (b) during the intervening period it be a condition of the right to drill that existing primary evacuation systems be improved or replaced so as to improve materially their capability to evacuate the crew".
When we checked with Cle Newhook, who is the leader of the New Democrats in Newfoundland and Labrador, he pointed out:
The major criticism of what Government has done re the Commission relates to section 107. Nothing substantially has been done by either level of government about this critical issue. The industry has put some R & D money into a modified version of davit launched lifeboat systems called P.R.O.D. Husky-Bow Valley was the main player in this development. Opinions may vary somewhat as to its usefulness, but few would claim that it solves the problem. The bottom line is we still do not have any effective way of safely evacuating workers from offshore installations in an emergency situation.
He points out that Canada is spending billions on space technology and it is ridiculous that we can retrieve people safely from space but not from our oceans.
It is clear that what has to happen in committee as this bill is reviewed in detail is that we have to give teeth to recommendation 107, that we have to ensure that the dollars are allocated, whether they be private sector or public sector, to develop that safe method of egress, that primary evacuation system.
We have to recognize that during this kind of evacuation it will probably be when aircraft are disabled, in times of very violent weather, which also precludes surface vessels travelling in a rapid way either to or from the rig. So we need some kind of cocoon that will not only remove the workers from a burning rig or a rig that is about to explode or to capsize, but will also safely protect them from the elements and allow them to survive their egression.
We have a responsibility to do that. If we do not, we are not justifying our efforts here. We are not protecting them as we are required to by law. It is the job of the Government of Canada to provide that protection. We might as well not have bothered with a Royal commission report. We might as well not bother with legislation like this unless we are serious about protecting those workers.

Government Orders
Yes, we can fight over which minister should be in charge of it, but the bottom line is we had damn well better find a way to protect those workers when they are out there. Otherwise, there will be another Royal commission and there will be more memorials because there will be more people who have lost their lives because we did not act.

Mr. Speaker, I want to pick up where my colleague the member for Thunder Bay-Atikokan left off.
Today we are debating the amendments to the Canada Oil and Gas Operations Act. Reservations have been expressed by members who have spoken in this debate, but it is important to say that, by and large, the amendments being proposed by the federal minister of energy today are welcomed in this House. There is provision within the act laid down before the House today to clarify many of the regulatory concerns raised by the Hickman royal commission and by industty, government, regulatory agencies and labour representatives, with respect to the operation of oil and gas works.
April 9, 1992

The House would be remiss if it did not indicate that the bill is a step in the right direction. This bill will improve the prospects for safe operation of oil and gas rigs and a safe work environment for people who are employed in the offshore. It is important that fact be acknowledged so all other comments that are meant to draw attention to the bill and establish some areas for discussion, debate and exploration when this bill goes to committee can be taken in the proper context.
It is important for people to realize we are not voting today to pass or reject this bill. We are having an initial discussion about a set of proposals that will be sent off to a special legislative committee drawn up of members of this House. They will examine the bill to see whether or not it can be improved, changed, passed in its current form or amended. That is what is going to happen, and I make my comments in that context.
I want to restrict my comments to the question of jurisdiction. When the Ocean Ranger disaster occurred in February 1982, 10 years ago, with the consequential loss of 84 lives, there was an absolute flurry of activity in the land. There were countless declarations of good intent all across this land. Within 10 days, almost a record-setting time frame, a royal commission was launched, off and running. The government said it wanted answers.
Within a month of the Ocean Ranger disaster, the Ocean Ranger Disaster Fund was established. Within a year of the disaster a scholarship fund was set up which sent 11 kids to university this year. There was a flurry of activity and a commitment to make life at sea aboard an oil and gas rig safer for the men and women who worked on it.
It is now 10 years after the fact. Despite all of the commitments of good will, good intent and quick action, we are only now getting technical amendments to the existing Oil and Gas Production and Conservation Act.
It has been 10 years since 84 men disappeared without a trace, their bodies never seen, in a north Atlantic storm. It is pretty tragic we are only now talking technical amendments. What is more tragic is that we still have a turf war going on within the federal government. It is shameful. How many Canadians realize that within the national government there is still a debate going on at
Government Orders
the level of senior bureaucrats and ministers over who is going to control the operation of offshore oil and gas rigs.
How many Canadians realize that every single vessel that plies the Atlantic Ocean within Canada's jurisdiction is governed by safety regulations laid down by the Canada Shipping Act, with the exception of oil and gas rigs? Why is it necessary to exempt oil and gas rigs that are ships from the Canada Shipping Act? They are self-propelled and everything that is self-propelled is a ship.
Why do they have to set up a separate division to regulate rigs within the department of energy? It is in the business of energy exploration and production, not safety. Can anybody give me one good reason, 10 years after 84 men died, why the department of energy should be allowed to retain its jurisdiction over those rigs? It is not a Tory, Liberal, or NDP problem. It is a bureaucratic problem.
Can anybody give one functional reason why it is better? How is anybody any safer? Is there one reason? There are no reasons.
The Hickman royal commission touched on that. It talked about the fact that oil and gas rigs were not treated as ships. The Hickman royal commission told us that the people who were aboard those vessels and who had ultimate authority were not qualified sea captains. They were not mariners. Why would they be, when the department of energy regulated the operation of the rigs? Its primary role and responsibility, quite properly, is to promote development, exploration and production of offshore oil and gas. It is a gross conflict of interest to have the same department that promotes oil and gas exploration also responsible for safety.
What does the minister do when there is a conflict between his desire to make an offshore oil and gas exploration happen and his responsibility to ensure that whatever costs associated with a safe operation are brought to bear on an offshore oil and gas rig? Where is the minister's priority? Is it cutting the cost and promoting exploration, or imposing an additional cost and burden and ensuring safety?

April 9, 1992
Government Orders
It is a conflict of interest. It is like putting a pyroma-niac in charge of the fire hall. It is outrageous, 10 years after the Ocean Ranger disaster that we allow this. Yes, it is touchy behaviour for a member to stand here and harp on the fact that 84 people died. Yes, it is tough for a member to stand here and remind us all that 84 families are without their loved ones. Yes, it touches a raw nerve and is tough rhetoric in debate. But we have to remind ourselves that offshore oil and gas safety is what we are concerned with here.
My purpose in rising today is to say to those members who will sit on the special committee and examine this bill that they cannot accept at face value the continued jurisdiction of the department of energy over the operation of oil and gas rigs. It is wrong.
It makes no sense. It is abnormal. It is the one exemption from the Canada Shipping Act. All other vessels that ply Canadian waters do so under regulations laid down by the Canada Shipping Act. There is absolutely no good reason why offshore oil and gas rigs should function in a different manner.
What does this bill before us provide for offshore oil and gas rigs? It provides that in some cases the department of energy will have jurisdiction over the operation of the rigs. It provides that in other cases the department of Indian and northern affairs will have jurisdiction over the operation of oil and gas rigs.
Why should that be? Why should the possibility of conflict even exist? Why should the possibility of different regulations being applied differently in different circumstances even exist when all it takes is the government deciding to take the advice of a $15 million royal commission into this disaster, to take the advice of many members of Parliament, to take the advice of Canada's mariners, to take the advice of the officials who are in the ship safety division of Transport Canada, and to transfer jurisdiction and responsibility for the safe operation of these rigs to the men and women within our public service whose sole purpose in breathing when they wake up in the morning is to ensure proper safe ship operation? Why should there be an exemption for oil and gas rigs?
I will tell you why. Because it is a turf war. It is a classic example of the transparently petty power game that goes on in the nation's capital. It is a transparent example of
the petty politics played between ministers and senior bureaucrats as to who is going to build the biggest kingdom, as to whether or not the minister of energy who is in charge and is responsible for promoting offshore oil and gas exploration and production is going to allow another minister on his turf.
That is what is going on here. That went on 10 years ago. That is what went on 15 years ago. It has not changed. It has not changed in the face of a tragic loss of life.
Perhaps that is one of the reasons why there is in Canada today a kind of profound cynicism about the political process and public life, a profound corrosive doubt about the ability of the system to work for the public good when we continue to allow in spite of all of the evidence to the contrary this kind of turf war to exist.
I point out that it is not unique to any particular party, but it is unique. This kind of turf war is commonly associated with big government wherever big government is found.
I hope my contribution to this debate will challenge the status quo as is represented by this regulatory regime as proposed under this bill, will challenge those members who will indeed I am sure with good will, good heart, and good conscience participate in the examination of this bill before the appropriate standing committee to take a look at whether or not it is appropriate for the minister of energy, the person in charge of getting offshore oil and gas exploration going and in charge of accelerating the pace of development, to also have his hand on the safety brake, and if he does have his hand on the safety brake, whether or not he is in a conflict of interest.
I submit no matter who that minister is, no matter what his or her intentions, no matter what their personal integrity, whether they are Tory or Liberal or New Democrat makes no difference, that minister is automatically put in a conflict. They have to decide whether the priority is development or safety. They have to decide whether or not in the name of efficiency to attract capital they scrap safety, or whether or not in the name of a decent working environment from time to time they impose an additional cost on those who want to participate in offshore oil and gas production. There is no need for that conflict. There is no need for one ministry to have both those roles. It is inappropriate, it is improper, and it ought to be changed.
April 9, 1992

Madam Speaker, I thank the member for his question.
The Hickman royal commission did not come down clearly on the side of any department. I must tell you that the Hickman royal commission very clearly said, and it was one of the major recommendations, that there ought to be one regulator. There ought to be a single department, a single ministry, in charge of the safe operation of the rigs. That is what the royal commission said. It did not say whether it ought to be energy, Indian and northern affairs, transport, federal, provincial. It stayed silent. I suspect the reason the commission stayed silent is that at that stage, if the member will recall because he was here in the House, there was a large debate going on about who owned the offshore. There were negotiations going on between the federal government of the day and the provincial government of the day as to whether or not there would be a joint regulatory regime. There was a court challenge at the same time.
I think some of those questions that were ongoing and that were unresolved at that point in time probably created a climate. Here I am guessing, surmising. The commissioners decided they would leave which department open to an appropriate decision by Parliament, but they clearly and very strongly-in fact it was one of the first and major recommendations-recommended one department.
Government Orders
What is important? What is relevant? Here we are, 10 years after the disaster, seven or eight years after the submission of both the preliminary and final reports, and we do not have one department. What we have is a statement in the explanatory note covering the new bill. I ask my friend to consider that. In the event of an emergency, in the event that a rig is offshore, is in trouble, is in a storm, is perhaps going to sink, perhaps we are going to have to abandon ship, the minister of energy will have the right to override all other departments and have sole jurisdiction over the rig.
I think it is rather pathetic, quite frankly, that 10 years after the Ocean Ranger disaster, the government is not doing what the royal commission recommended, giving to one department the responsibility for safety. I submit it ought to be the Department of Transport because it is a disinterested, honest player. Transport's role is ship safety. Transport Canada has a ship safety branch. It exists only for one purpose. It has no other purpose in life but to maintain, propose and execute proper procedures for ship safety. It is not in the business of exploring for oil. It is not in the business of granting licences for blocks of Canada lands. It is not in the business in the case of Petro-Canada of being an 80 per cent shareholder in an oil company.
The minister of energy holds, on behalf of the people of Canada, 80 per cent of the shares of Petro-Canada. He is a shareholder. He is in the business of exploring for oil and gas. Is he going to impose upon himself, holding the shares of Petro-Canada on behalf of the people of Canada, additional costs, being the chief safety officer? He is in a rabid, he is in an unmitigated, he is in a transparent, he is in an obvious, he is in a painfully ridiculous conflict of interest. How can you both be a shareholder of an oil exploration company and the chief safety officer on behalf of the people of Canada?
It ought not be the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources. It ought to be the Minister of Transport who has that responsibility because he is disinterested. He does not have a conflict. He does not wear two hats, one as promoter and one as safety officer. He wears only one. The member should know that a ship is defined in the Canada Shipping Act as any self-propelled vehicle that plies the ocean. An oil rig is self-propelled. Most rigs today are self-propelled but they are the only exception
