Madam Speaker, as usual, my friend from Humber-St. Barbe- Baie Verte is more than generous. It is my pleasure to follow him in this debate.
As he and others have said, we should remember that what we are doing here is moving this legislation off to committee. At committee there will be a broad discussion on a number of aspects of this legislation.
We should also remember that this legislation does not apply just to offshore of Newfoundland and Labrador, in fact it applies right across the industry. It has particular importance for the frontier which is, in this country, quite broad and quite inclusive.
I suppose it is the tragedy of February 14 and 15, 1982 that makes us focus on this tragedy which was quite personal for many of us. Not only did many Newfoundlanders and Labradorians lose family members and, like me, lose friends, but it was something that was felt right through the community. Those of us who have lived by
April 9, 1992

and from the sea for so long, while recognizing constant danger and being aware of constant loss of life, do become perhaps a little bit immune, a little bit brave and with a perception of indestructibility.
The window at the back of my house at the time looked right out over the harbour with an unimpeded view. The view of the support vessels that returned to that harbour carrying equipment and tragically bodies was something that remains with me today. It reminds us that we are fragile and it reminds us that we do live a very dangerous life by the sea.
At the time, St. John's particularly, but all of the island part of our province, was excited by oil and gas. There were great prospects: there were jobs, there were ships coming and going, there were rigs in Marystown and rigs sitting outside St. John's, drill ships inside the harbour, supply boats coming and going, helicopters overhead all the time, and people getting ready for what they thought would be an opportunity to make some money and create some jobs. I tell you that Monday morning sure brought us down to earth very quickly with a thump.
It has been 10 years, but anybody who was living in St. John's or Newfoundland at the time will ever forget it. We see the results every day. Those of us who have lost family members or know people who have lost family members continue to deal with the tragedy. We are reminded through memorials and particularly through the efforts of a number of groups such as scholarship funds and others.
We are reminded again as we deal with Bill C-58, which seeks to address almost all of the concerns that were raised in the subsequent investigations, studies, royal commissions and task forces, first of all, to get an idea of what caused this tragedy. Why did the great Ocean Ranger sink? Why was there such a huge loss of life? Why was there such a tragic result on that awful February night? Winds had been experienced before and high seas had been experienced before and supposedly all of the precautions had been taken.
We have heard a lot about the royal commission, the Hickman study, the Ocean Ranger inquiry. For three years that kept us all focused not only on that particular tragedy, but on the work that was done and the net that was expanded to look at technologies that were available around the world, at standards that were being used around the world and at conditions that existed around the world for the production of oil and gas off our shores.
Government Orders
There have been private sector task forces. We have heard about the consultations that have taken place, consultations that have been conducted not only by the Department of Energy, Mines and Resources, but by other departments. For instance, Labour Canada has conducted consultations with the trade unions and with the labour movement to deal particularly with health and safety measures, in committees and that sort of process.
That of course is being fed into the ongoing and ever expanding discussion among government departments, with provincial governments, with territorial governments and with industry in a variety of ways, styles and processes. We do have a body of knowledge that allows us to finally put the last touches in place.
As all members of the House know, immediately after the tragedy there was a move to put standards in place that would govern offshore drilling units: ballasting, structural integrity, survival suits and lifeboat requirements. It was done immediately.
By the time the Hickman study came out half of its recommendations had been put in place. It should be remembered that the study came out in two parts. The first part had 66 recommendations that dealt with rig designs, evacuation, search and rescue, training and that sort of thing. The second part had 70 recommendations dealing with offshore safety.
The recommendations were extensive. They had been widely studied. We have gathered the information, the studies that were available at the time, and a fairly broad approach to doing new research and gathering new information.
Over a period of time most of the recommendations, as I said, had been put in place.
Where there has been a problem, where there have been delays from 1986-87 after the Harrison task force did its work, has been somewhat, as my friend has said, not what to do but how best to do it. How can we most efficiently and effectively put in place the regulations to ensure that the management of the regulatory authorities was efficient, effective and transparent. How to ensure that the lines of authority were clear and delineated. How to ensure that the resources of government, the agencies that are responsible for safety, industry and all of the stakeholders quite clearly understood their roles and responsibilities and knew what to do if there were questions and knew what to do as we evolve new

April 9, 1992
Government Orders
regulations, as we evolve new technologies and we move forward.
We have seen the appointment of the Oil and Gas Administration Advisory Council and the Offshore Oil and Gas Training Standards Advisory Board, as the minister has said. But what has gone on in the last 10 years? We have seen ups and downs in exploration. We have seen what we thought were the first steps toward serious development off the east coast.
I need not tell this House how worried many of us are with the backing out of Gulf and the impact that has, not only on the Hibernia situation but oil and gas development generally. We are hopeful today that partners are in Asia pursuing opportunities there with the assistance of energy, mines and resources and the co-operation of government departments.
We have spent a lot of money on R and D, developing new equipment, developing new mechanisms that can get people off and away from a rig or a ship that is in danger. We have worked on new equipment that allows for survival in water. We have spent a lot of time training people in the area of safety in the offshore and have dealt with the whole question of being 275 kilometres from the nearest land in some of the roughest water in the world.
We heard a lot this morning about the question of jurisdiction, the question of control, the question of turf. It strikes me that this bill makes it very clear who, if there were a turf battle or had been a turf battle, is now to be in charge. The responsibility of departments and the authority of ministers is laid out.
There may be a dispute over which minister it should be. We have heard from the New Democratic Party members who have variously said the Minister of Labour and the Minister of Transport. We have heard from the Liberals who believe it should be the Minister of Transport. I want, briefly, to address that.
My friend from the west coast of Newfoundland was right when he said that the Hickman commission stated that there has to be a minister. It did not say which.
The private sector task force that sat down to review and advise government on these matters and reported in 1986 under Roland Harris suggested that it should be the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources. Why? My friend keeps asking why the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources and not the Minister of Transport?
I think there are a couple of things that we have to recognize. The first is that we are dealing not just with a vessel, a ship, a self-propelled rig. These regulations cover the marine safety and the industrial safety, the industrial operation of this very expensive, very complex and potentially very dangerous piece of equipment.
That has to be kept in mind. It should be remembered, and I want to make it perfectly clear, that the rigs operating offshore Newfoundland are subject to the provisions of the Canada Shipping Act. They are not exempt from the Canada Shipping Act.
As such, the Minister of Transport, the Department of Transport and Coast Guard have a role to play. It is an important role, but transport, like other departments, gets into this conflict. We have heard about the government through EMR owning shares in Petro-Canada, giving leases and providing safety.
Transport and so many other departments find themselves in exactly the same conflict. They set the policy. They write the regulations. They enforce the regulations. In many cases, they provide for the penalties for breach of those regulations.
They, as well, play a role through search and rescue in their co-operation with DND through the Coast Guard. Therefore, those conflicts potentially exist all over the place. What is important to recognize is that we have provided for one minister to co-ordinate the responsibilities of a variety of departments.
When there is an emergency situation or a situation that demands action, that minister has the ultimate responsibility and therefore the tools at his or her disposal to exercise that responsibility and that authority.
We must recognize that this is not only a marine industry. It is a very complicated industrial problem as well with the combination of the need to address worker safety so that we ensure all aspects of the operation are
April 9, 1992

safe and the need to protect the workers wherever they are in the frontiers of this country.
One of the colleagues of my friend from Gander-Grand Falls suggested that we were afraid to hear him. I am always delighted to hear the member for Gander-Grand Falls. Occasionally he speaks on the matters before the House. He is always entertaining. He speaks always from a caring and compassionate point of view. He does not always make sense. None of us do, I suspect. He has raised a couple of points. He talks about what is not in the bill. I know his interest will take him to the committee. I know he will find out in the committee that of course this legislation does not specifically deal with a couple of things he is most concerned about. One is the question of evacuation, and the other is the question of search and rescue.
He will find out that the question of evacuation and those related issues will be dealt with in the regulations as they are with all other legislation. They do not appear in the bill. They appear in the regulations and are quite definitively addressed in DND's search and rescue program.
I know when he participates in this committee, he will find these things out. I know his contribution will be substantial and important.
The tragedy that befell so many in Newfoundland in 1982 was felt around the world. The media attention at the time was frightening. The outpouring of support and understanding was exhilarating. The loss was tragic. We saw journalists from around the world. We saw family members come back. We saw people putting out their hands of support and generosity. Yes, we saw the vultures too. We learned a lot about ourselves, our history and our fragility. The fact is, we are not indestructible on the sea regardless of how careful we are and how much respect we have.
This legislation must ensure the work that has gone on in the last 10 years finalizes the package of what we know today. Part of making the package final is to ensure mechanisms are in place to continue to develop regulations and improve safety. We must continue to protect the workers, the environment and the future. We must do this not only for the benefit of offshore oil and gas
Government Orders
development but for our environment and those who can benefit and make a contribution to this world.
I know the study at committee will be thorough and will lead to productive discussions. I am sure all members will want to be constructive, helpful and positive as we put this behind us, having benefited, if at all possible, in some small way from this terrible tragedy.

subtopic: OIL AND GAS PRODUCTION AND CONSERVATION ACT
speechtext:
listened with interest to the debate this morning on Bill C-58 and the opinions of all members. They are very concerned with the safety regulations with respect to our offshore drilling rigs, and indeed all of our vessels.

April 9, 1992
Government Orders
I am somewhat concerned with this bill, and the fact it does not do everything we hoped it would do. I join with other members in the House who were deeply saddened by the tragedy that happened on the Ocean Ranger 10 years ago in February. We must be very cognizant of the legislation we are putting forward today and make sure we do everything we can to ensure such a tragedy never recurs.
As the member for St. John's East has said, it is not only a question of this bill and the ultimate legislation. It is also a question of the subsequent regulations that relate to this legislation. I hope both will get a very careful screening and the government will give us its undertaking that this bill will be studied very carefully in committee. Witnesses must be invited to attend as much as possible, and when the regulations come forward they must be reviewed by the Standing Committee on Energy.
I think we all regret it has taken so long to bring forward this legislation. We would like to show to the families of those who lost loved ones in the Ocean Ranger that we can work much more quickly than we have to bring forward this legislation. I do not think this is a true testimony to the concern of Canadians for those who lost their lives on the Ocean Ranger and the concern of Canadians that this not happen again. I think there has been undue delay. The inquiry, which presented its report in 1986, was not sufficiently complicated to warrant the time it has taken to bring this bill before this House.
It is reassuring in the time it has taken to bring the legislation before the House that people think even though it is taking too long to come forward we will ultimately get the legislation and regulations and have the proper protection. I am not convinced the proper protection now exists. This is going to be of concern for those who work on the drilling rigs and have eagerly awaited this legislation. They know the drilling rigs and the situations they are faced with. They know they must have that protection. It is in everyone's interest to have the safety structure there. The Canada Oil and Gas Operations Act must be sufficient for the job that has to be done.
The hon. member for St. John's East said he is not concerned that the minister of energy has the ultimate say in safety matters that relate to this bill. One of the reasons he used was that this relates not only to ocean safety but to industrial safety. That is not a point I would accept as confirming the fact that the minister of energy
should be the ultimate voice in this procedure. I do not accept that for a minute.
Industrial safety is a major factor but there is a lead time to correct the problem before and after it occurs. We are not going to lose a complete drilling rig in the event of this industrial accident. Certainly industrial accidents can be harmful and people can be killed but a whole rig and crew can be completely swallowed up by the ocean in a matter of minutes. The ultimate care of the rig itself has to be paramount when we determine who is going to make the ultimate decision in safety matters regarding offshore drilling rigs.
There is no question a drilling rig is a vessel. It is propelled and it is in the ocean. Even if it is not a vessel, it is sitting in the middle of the ocean. The Hibernia is over 250 kilometres from shore and in some of the roughest water in the world.
For somebody to appreciate the savagery of the ocean he or she would have to be there. You cannot possibly just describe it. It is frightening to say the least for those on the drilling rigs. It will be more frightening if the workers on the drilling rigs do not feel they have ultimate safety.
One could say we are not helping matters by saying we do not feel there are adequate safety provisions. That may be the case, but it is not for this House to say. We do not want to alarm people by saying there are problems and leaving it at that. It is much better to alarm and make the changes needed.
The question, of course, is what changes can be made. I believe as others do that the Minister of Transport should have the ultimate say in this question of safety on the ocean. The drilling rig is a vessel, and the question of ocean safety has already been studied by the Department of Transport. The Department of Transport deals in ocean transportation and has people in the department who are knowledgeable on that subject. They are involved in the safety of ordinary standard vessels. They are involved in clean-up mechanisms when there is a spill. They are involved in that. They supervise the Coast Guard. They supervise control aircraft. On land they have an excellent department that looks after the transportation of dangerous goods. They are involved in safety. They have a lot of expertise on safety matters, particularly on the water. That is not to say the Department of Transport should have all safety matters. For instance, the Department of Labour looks after safety in mines and so on. You cannot transport that to the Department of Transport, no pun intended.
April 9, 1992

I do feel that in this case the Minister of Transport should have the ultimate authority. I have no objection to the minister of energy or the department of energy. That is not a reflection on them and any subsequent minister. I think the minister, whoever he or she may be, will do the best job possible. It is just when the ultimate decision has to be made in an ocean disaster or a potential problem on the ocean it has to be made quickly. If you do not make it quickly, you are going to have a lot of time to reflect on it because it will be too late.
The problem is that these things happen very suddenly and that decisions have to be made suddenly. Also, if you have to make a sudden decision, you have to know who to contact to get confirmation as to what you are doing is correct. You have to get the expertise in a moment's notice. You have to know who to call. You have to know the systems that are in place, the search vessels, the search planes. The whole procedure has to be dealt with very, very quickly. I do not feel that the minister of energy can make those instantaneous decisions and contacts.
I also do not think that the minister of energy is going to be doing himself any favour by putting himself in this position. If a delay occurs, and a delay could occur for very innocent reasons, for instance, not having all of the facts, not realizing the seriousness of the situation, not waiting for further information, it could be blamed on the minister's inability to make that decision when he or she may not have all of the information or may not be apprised of the seriousness.
Also, if a decision is not made quickly and properly by a minister of energy, the minister of energy is open to the allegation that he or she was more concerned about protecting an asset of an oil company, a drilling rig or some equipment company and the safety of the workers was not paramount in the minister's mind. That would be tragic. It would be tragic that that kind of reflection could be placed upon the minister.
I think that we have to avoid any chance of aspersions being cast on the minister. A system should be in place to do the best job possible as quickly as possible. It is not
only a question of efficiency. It is a question of cost effectiveness and the fact that we must in this country in the days of technological advances and the importance of maintaining certainly the most important aspect, the importance of maintaining human life, deal with things in the best manner possible.
Co-ordination is vital. It has to be there to the nth degree, more so than even in oil spills. In oil spills, you are going to damage property, but with regard to ocean safety, you are most certainly faced with loss of life. The case of the Ocean Ranger with the loss of 84 lives is a tragedy which will be with us for as long as we all live in Atlantic Canada.
The member for St. John's East knows, as he said, some of the people and certainly the families of those who lost their lives. It was unquestionably a terrible, terrible tragedy.
Have we really looked at it? Someone has got to bear the ultimate responsibility. You cannot have a lot of departments involved without somebody having the ultimate responsibility. You have to know whom to contact to ask questions. The search and rescue operations are a vital part of ocean safety, but they have not been integrated to the extent that would satisfy me, frankly. The technology for launching the lifeboats from a drilling rig has not been answered.
The most difficult feature is getting the lifeboats into the water and having the people in the lifeboats live. These drilling rigs are monstrous structures. You need to have a lifeboat that goes from that drilling platform into an ocean that could have 100-foot waves and winds howling at 100 knots an hour. It is incredible out there. You need to have them enclosed so that the men cannot fall out, not only when they are being launched, but when they are in the water. It is an awful thing. Even if they live, they are subject to such motion sickness that you cannot even possibly comprehend, but the main thing is they will live if the proper precautions are taken.
With the Ocean Ranger it is assumed, and I do not know if anyone knows for sure, that one lifeboat did get launched, but that lifeboat was sunk by the collapsing drilling rig. We do not know how many men were in that lifeboat, if any, but that is a tragic assumption.

April 9, 1992
What we have to make sure of is that the boats are launched far enough away from the drilling rig so that if the platform collapses it does not crash down on the lifeboats. There is no assurance that will not happen but that has to be taken into consideration.
I do not feel that the necessary consideration has been given to lifeboat launching. I say that without having all the particular knowledge, but I am not convinced. I hope that those who serve on the drilling rigs will be more convinced than I am.
I reflect back to the disaster in 1980 in the Norwegian waters when they had a drilling rig loss. They made sure that the rig could actually remain stationary if it lost one of its support legs. They have also developed a system of putting the lifeboats on to a slide and launching them that way into the water. A great deal of care was taken. I hope care has been taken here, I really do. I would invite the government to make sure, through careful hearing at legislative time in front of the committee, that experts be invited to come forward to testily and that the subsequent regulations be looked at veiy carefully.
If the government is prepared to do that then that will ease my concern tremendously because we need expert opinion on this. I think we should be inviting that expert opinion.

Mr. Speaker, Canada and Quebec today signed a four-year $136 million forestry development agreement to be financed equally by both of them.
This is a result of the work done by the Conservative members from Quebec in Ottawa, headed by the hon. member for Champlain. This agreement provides significant support for the forest economy in rural Quebec and direct and indirect benefits for various Quebec interest groups.
In recent months the Conservative government renewed two other agreements, namely those for industrial development and for tourism.
Quebec's mining industry awaits the signature of a Canada-Quebec subagreement on mineral development.

Mr. Speaker, for the past few days the media has been seized with the national crisis of the NHL players' strike. I, too, love hockey. I grew up with international champions, the Trail Smoke Eaters. I also strongly believe in free collective bargaining and the player-worker right to withdraw their labour.
My argument is not with the NHL players who are seeking a fair settlement. My argument is with Canada's media who played this dispute as the lead story from coast to coast to coast. Hey there, story editors, where are your priorities?
Where are the national headlines about the giant Bank of Commerce, for example, which has locked out 22 women for 15 months for trying to get a first agreement? What are these women asking for? An end
April 9, 1992

to wage discrimination, seniority for casuals, protection from harassment.
These women are stars too. Let us get our priorities right and give them equal play.

Mr. Speaker, the 1992 Citation for Citizenship Awards were presented in Ottawa yesterday to honour individuals and organizations for their outstanding contributions to Canadian citizenship.
One of these national awards was presented to Mr. Osmond T. Anderson of Winnipeg, currently chairperson of the Manitoba Multicultural Resources Centre and the founding chairperson of the city of Winnipeg Community and Race Relations Committee. O.T., as he is commonly known by thousands of Winnipeg students, is also the vice-principal of Daniel McIntyre High School. O.T. has been a volunteer in Winnipeg for numerous organizations. The efforts of citizens like O.T. are greatly appreciated as well as needed in our ever changing multicultural society.
On behalf of all Manitobans, I would like to thank O.T. Anderson for his contributions in the areas of race relations, multiculturalism and citizenship. I know that all members of the House join me in congratulating O.T. on receiving this award.

Mr. Speaker, Canadians expect and demand that our federal government invest hard-earned tax dollars in Canadian products and in the communities and Canadians who produce them.
Some say our federal government does not invest in Canadians. How can this be when our government invests heavily on an ongoing basis in the very infrastructure of Canada? The infrastructure of our airports has been invested in. Recently, in Kelowna, British Columbia, the government invested $200 million in Western Star Thicks, and in my riding of London-Middlesex, $800 million in General Motors Diesel. Both of these projects are to improve the infrastructure of Canada's armed services.
These continued investments acknowledge loudly and clearly to the world that the government has faith and pride in Canadian excellence. On behalf of the people of London-Middlesex, I call upon our government to continue its obvious investment in Canadian infrastructure and excellence. The people of our country deserve no less.

Mr. Speaker, in its latest budget, the federal government expects the economy to grow 2.7 per cent in 1992. The Royal Bank is more realistic: it predicts a 1.4 per cent growth rate.
The message is clear: the recession brought on by too high interest rates and an overvalued dollar will continue. This means that the federal debt will continue to grow.
Quebec is caught in this system. The federal government is running up a scandalous debt, over which we have no control. Canadian federalism is bankrupt. The glorious heritage that awaits us is a monumental debt.
It is obvious that Quebec has no interest remaining in the Canadian federation with that kind of result.

Mr. Speaker, there has been a lot of criticism in this House of the decision to shelve the national child care program. I also believe that the government should help parents who need to work to escape poverty.
However, do New Democrats help parents who need help to escape poverty? Absolutely not.
In Ontario, the NDP is currently implementing a $105 million program to convert privately operated day care, which provides 27 per cent of the spaces in Ontario, to non-profit co-ops. This program will not add a single day care space.
These small businesses will receive compensation for toys only and will lose their subsidy agreements if they do not donate their capital investment to new, non-profit co-op boards, although they meet all licensing requirements and have parent advisory committees.

April 9, 1992
Less than 8 per cent of children who need care in Ontario are in licensed facilities. This will mean there will be even fewer opportunities for poorer parents for licensed care and much higher costs.
Management that is ideologically acceptable for socialists-

Mr. Speaker, 189,000 Montrealers are unemployed, 12.9 per cent of our work force, and the numbers are continuing to grow under the economic mismanagement of the Conservative government.
The city is losing jobs in the high-tech field, a sector that the Prime Minister and the Minister of Finance have described as the future of Canada's economy.

The loss of 500 jobs at Phillips in Saint-Laurent adds to the list of employers in the Montreal area who have had to cut employment. The Montreal area is wasting away under the Conservative government which is unable to improve the lot of the jobless in our city.

We need to create an economic climate that will help companies like Phillips flourish, not falter. We need to help Montreal develop a core of high technology companies that will be competitive throughout the world.
As well, this Conservative government and the minister responsible for Montreal are doing nothing to address the many other sectors such as textile, clothing, and small business. Our municipal infrastructure is badly in need of repair.
If this government will not do it, the Liberal government will.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to inform the House that the federal Minister of Forestry, the Quebec Minister of Forests, Albert Cote, signed a four-year federal-provincial subagreement on forest development this morning. This agreement, a calm in the present constitutional storm, provides $136 million, to be paid equally by both of the governments involved.
I am glad that private forest producers will benefit most from this agreement, because most of the funds, $100 million, will be for private forest development in Quebec. A major thrust of the private forest development program will be a silviculture initiative emphasizing the development of some 80,000 hectares of natural forest and the replanting of about 46,400 hectares of private forest.
The agreement signed this morning also provides for the development and implementation of a geo-forest information system and for forest development on the Upper North Shore.
I congratulate the federal Minister of Forestry, and his parliamentary secretary, the hon. member for Champlain, on successfully negotiating this issue.

Mr. Speaker, no problem can be more immediate yet at the same time have such lasting consequence as the inability of a growing number of people in our world to find enough food to eat.
While permanent solutions to this human suffering lie in the creation of a lasting world peace, investment in the individual and- environmentally sustainable development, we must find the time and the means to address the fact that today and every day in Canada and around the world, people are going hungry.
April 9, 1992

This Saturday, April 11, we in Ottawa South are organizing the third annual Stop Hunger Fast, a nonpartisan hunger awareness event. Over the day, we hope to collect food, raise money through a 24-hour fast and find volunteers for the Ottawa Food Bank and UNICEF.
The Stop Hunger Fast will be held at the Heron Gate Mall in Ottawa. We are hoping that our residents will take the time to learn about how we can stop hunger and to celebrate the efforts of those organizations which are working to this end.
The world is capable of producing enough food to feed all of its people. Let us endeavour to put an end to our collective failure to ensure that it is distributed to those in need.

Mr. Speaker, the government is going to have to face a problem with the original design of the GRIP as introduced last year complete with its so-called offsets.
If a farmer grows a better than average crop he gets little or no GRIP payment. If he has been unable to deliver that crop to market he has no money. Farmers expected the spring GRIP payment to at least equal the fall payment which for most farmers did not pay the outstanding premium. Since the GRIP payout is the difference between the coverage levels minus product times price, the projected payout will decrease as price rises.
The $10 per tonne increase to the initial wheat price over winter means that the spring GRIP payout will disappoint a lot of farmers, particularly those who produce a better than average crop.
I call on the government to provide another increase to Wheat Board initial prices so that grain growers will have some cash available to help pay for fuel, parts, seed, fertilizer and chemicals to put in this spring's crop.

Mr. Speaker, the Atlantic Canada's sustainable futures exposition
for Truro, N.S., better known as Going Green in '93, will be a major exposition which addresses many aspects of environmental concerns and our long term sustainable future.
The business of the environment and the environment of business will be the next driver of our economy in the future. Even now international trade agreements negotiated must deal with environmental issues unheard of just a few years ago.
Going Green in '93 is a timely project which will establish Atlantic Canada as a leader in sustainable development. It will be funded by the municipality of Truro, the province, the federal government, the private sector and the approximate 300,000 visitors.
At the moment we are seeking tangible support from all levels so that the project can proceed. The municipality is on side. Now it would be helpful for the Minister of the Environment to express his commitment and provide assistance to keep up the momentum.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this is the 75th anniversary of the battle of Vimy Ridge, the victory claimed by Canadians, fighting together for the first time as Canadians.
Both the British and the French had failed before them, but Canadians attained what some thought impossible.
But what a price they paid: more than 3,000 dead, almost another 8,000 wounded men and, yes, boys from all parts of Canada whose spirit of sacrifice and courage almost defies description.
Yet that spirit lives today. In the last few hours we have all seen on television pictures of 14 Canadians, the youngest 91 years old, revisiting the battlefield. Their effort to honour the memory of their comrades in arms today are as noble as their gallantry 75 years ago.
That was and is the spirit that won Vimy. That was and is the spirit that built this great country.

Mr. Speaker, as many members have been reminding us this week, today we are marking the 75th anniversary of the battle of Vimy Ridge.
This is an appropriate occasion to pledge that our Canadian veterans and their loved ones will continue to receive more than rhetoric from a grateful nation.
It is so easy to make promises in the patriotic fever of war. It is not so easy to keep them in the cold dawn of post-war budgeting. But we have kept ours.
It is to Canada's credit that various governments have kept their word. Looking back to the thirties, Parliament introduced the War Veterans Allowance, which was a trail blazer for Canada's social safety network. The allowance recognized that someone who had spent their youth in the trenches of France was likely to age more quickly than someone who had spent the war by the fireside.
More recently the Veterans' Independence Program was brought in to help veterans stay in their own homes and out of institutions. This program is one of the finest ever launched by Veterans Affairs.
We can say in all truth that 75 years after Vimy and 50 years after Dieppe we continue to show our gratitude through veterans legislation worthy of the men and women who risked their lives in the name of Canada.

Mr. Speaker, the federal government's withdrawal from social housing is a tragic move that will leave thousands of Canadians out in the cold.
Social housing is vital to the welfare of thousands of Canadians. An estimated 200,000 households are on waiting lists nationally for affordable housing. Yet, the
latest federal budget has slashed the planned commitment for social housing by 34 per cent.
The budget has terminated the Co-operative Housing Program which is one of the most effective means of providing community housing. A Liberal government introduced the program in 1973, believing in the philosophy of the co-operative sector. It recognized that co-operative housing is affordable housing. It creates jobs for builders, helps fashion a strong community base and offers hope to some 800,000 households in Canada in core housing need.
I appeal to the government to reinstate funding to social housing and the Co-operative Housing Program. Too many Canadians rely on housing assistance for the government to simply turn its back on them.

Mr. Speaker, while Canadians rightly condemn the use of violence against the Embassy of Iran in Ottawa, Iran's bombing of Iranian resistance forces based in Iraq last weekend was the latest in a long series of violations of international law by the Iranian government.
Last month the UN Commission on Human Rights condemned Iran for the eleventh year in a row for gross and systematic human rights violations. The death sentence against British author Salman Rushdie by the late Ayatollah Khomeini continues to stand, forcing Rushdie to live in hiding.
The Iranian government recently expelled the International Red Cross Committee in spite of having agreed last fall with the UN General Assembly to allow them to visit Iranian prisons.
In 1990 Amnesty International reported that Iran executed over 5,000 political prisoners and others in the three previous years. Amnesty is also concerned about killings of Iranian opposition activists outside Iran.
Western governments, including Canada, must end the policy of rapprochement with Iran as long as it maintains repression against its own people and continues to violate fundamental human rights.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, last year we commemorated one of Canada's most significant
April 9, 1992

battles, remembering the sacrifice of a generation of Newfoundlanders at Beaumont-Hamel. This year we are commemorating two others. Seventy-five years ago the Canadian Corps stormed Vimy Ridge and won universal admiration.
British Prime Minister David Lloyd George wrote that it was the Canadians who were brought into the line to lead one great allied assault after another.
It was the same story 50 years ago. A different war, a different part of France, but again it was Canadians who were picked to lead an allied strike force against the enemy. We can look back with pride at the bravery of Canadians who took part in the Dieppe raid. They were given an impossible task and they did not flinch.
Vimy, Dieppe and so many other battles saw Canadians at their best. We must remember so we do not repeat. I call on the government to spare no effort in honouring those who have participated in these great events.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of the Environment.
The report on the state of the environment tabled today paints a devastating picture of the pollution of drinking water in Canada. Serious health problems are to be expected. Nevertheless, the green plan promised that a drinking water bill would be passed last year.
Can the minister tell us specifically how this bill, which we are still waiting for, will assure Canadians that they can safely drink tap water?

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
First of all, Mr. Speaker, I would like to take this opportunity to report to the House that a very comprehensive, in fact perhaps the most comprehensive state of the environment report being prepared anywhere in the world, has been tabled today. As you know, this is the second such report, the first having been made available in 1986.
Canada, in co-operation with industry and many groups throughout the community, has set the stage for
Oral Questions
this state of the environment report. We have provided the lead and other nations of the world are following us.
With respect specifically to the question of water quality which is a very important issue, as the hon. member has already said there has been some very significant progress made as indicated in the report.
As the hon. member will know, because I am sure he has read the report very carefully, there are several indications of progress, including the fact that the federal government, in co-operation with provincial governments and municipal governments, is now able to report that sewage treatment has increased from 63 per cent to 70 per cent of those communities with a population of over 1,000. Last week, speaking about the Kitty Nowdluck case, the commissioner of the RCMP said: "A number of very obvious errors were committed and she, once a victim, became almost a victim again". He then said an internal review had addressed the officers involved in the case.
I have now learned that last year the RCMP cleared all officers who worked on the case.
Why did the RCMP commissioner admit mishandling the case and not discipline the officers involved?

speakeroldname: Hon. Doug Lewis (Solicitor General of Canada):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, regrettably I am not in a position to discuss this matter because it is before a public complaints commission hearing at the present time. I think the hearing has been completed and we are waiting for the decision of the commissioner.

April 9, 1992

OLYMPIA & YORK

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance.
There is public speculation that Revenue Canada is prepared to allow Olympia & York to issue distress shares and allow Canada's poor banks out of the problem they find themselves in.
In light of the fact that small businesses do not qualify for these distress shares and in light of the fact that the Canadian taxpayer, the Canadian people, ought to know what it is going to cost them when this thing shakes down, will the minister disclose what this government is prepared to do to bail out those poor Canadian banks from their entanglement with Olympia & York?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the remarks of my hon. friend are sheer speculation. I can only advise him, as I have advised the House on other occasions, that the Department of Finance is monitoring the situation and there is nothing further to report.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of Finance. In the latest federal budget the Minister of Finance predicted that economic growth would be around 2.7 per cent. Yesterday, the president of the Royal Bank predicted it would be 1.4 per cent. I am more inclined to believe the president of the Royal Bank. It means that this year, the annual deficit will again be $30 billion. This works out to a cumulative debt for Quebec of about $6 billion. Did the Minister of Finance ask the Government of Quebec for permission to incur another $6 billion worth of debt on its behalf?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member has raised a question with respect to assumptions and projections.
I can only advise the hon. member that when we prepared the budget we prepared it on the basis of the assumptions that were available at that particular time
Business of the House
and in accordance with the private sector forecast. A number of private forecasters are adjusting their growth projections downward. The IMF and the OECD are doing likewise.
I should remind the hon. member that at the time we brought the budget down organizations such as the Royal Bank, OECD, IMF, and the Conference Board of Canada were projecting growth well in excess of what we were projecting. They were in excess of 3 per cent.
There has been some weakening in the economy. There has been some weakening in industrialized economies. Obviously we have to take that into consideration. We will be making those kinds of adjustments as we deem necessary.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am wondering if the government could indicate what the business of the House will be for the remainder of today and tomorrow and for the first day back after the recess.
While the minister is on his feet perhaps he could indicate to the House when he might convene a House leaders meeting in order to discuss the referendum legislation. speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in terms of business, we expect to complete second reading of Bill C-46, an act respecting contraventions of federal enactments, this afternoon.

April 9, 1992
Business of the House
We will then call and hopefully complete third reading of Bill C-56, an act respecting the control of government expenditures. Discussions are now ongoing between the three parties in terms of other business for tomorrow.
In terms of plebiscite-referendum legislation, as indicated the hopes and to a degree the expectations of the government are that we will reach an agreement between the provinces for the successful conclusion of constitutional amendments that will keep the country united. In the event that it becomes advisable for a plebiscite to be held across the country then action will be taken at that point in time.
I understand that the committee, under the chairmanship of the government Whip, looking into electoral reform has been considering this question as well. Certainly we would expect at some time in the near future, depending on events at the constitutional table and so on, it may well be appropriate to bring forward some legislation respecting plebiscites. Of course the usual consultations among the parties would occur at that time.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, with regard to the activities of the committee of which the chief government Whip is chairman, I do not believe-and perhaps we could have another debate at another time-that it would be in order to refer the subject matter of referendum legislation to that committee. In fact it might be some other committee.
I am wondering if the government Blouse leader would not think it wise to convene a House leaders meeting earlier as opposed to some later date in order that we can discuss this matter and agree to the appropriate committee which would be seized with the legislation. I presume the government House leader and PCO would probably have the bill ready to table in this House at a moment's notice.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
I want to make it clear that there are two questions at issue. One is the mechanism for holding a plebiscite-referendum. Logic would dictate that the Elections Act would probably form the basis for doing that. In other words, one would hold a national plebiscite in the same manner as one would hold a national election in terms of eligibility, enumeration, et cetera.
The second question and the more important question by far as to what questions to be put to the people of
Canada is a question that cannot even be contemplated until it is clear that is the only recourse for moving along the constitutional file in a way that will result in a successful conclusion.
The specific details of how a referendum campaign would be conducted and the mechanisms are in the Elections Act. Whatever minor modifications are necessary in view of the fact that the answer is yes and no as opposed to which candidate do you select can be accommodated through a change in the law.
At the appropriate time that will be brought forward. The hon. member is right. There are variations of that in draft form. I will always welcome the opportunity to meet with the hon. member at any particular time. However, I am not sure what useful purpose would come from such a meeting in respect of this issue.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am not seeking a meeting for the purposes of having a meeting with the hon. member. I am sure he and I have other things and other responsibilities that we must attend to.
I want to be clear. Is the hon. member now saying that within the department, either the Privy Council Office or the Department of Justice, there is a bill with regard to referendum? If so, and if he does not wish to table it at this time, would the hon. member at least give us an opportunity to sit down and discuss the contents of that bill?
He has made some references to the Elections Act. We would be interested in knowing exactly where the government House leader wishes to go in terms of this possible legislation. We are not trying to obstruct in any way. We are just trying to elicit more information so that all of us can be ready and be prepared to go at the opportune time.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
The rules are very clear: first reading, second reading, committee stage, report stage, third reading.
There will be more than enough opportunity for everyone in the House to examine the legislation, if and when it is brought forward, and to amend it in committee. This type of legislation is normally of the type where there is general consensus, if not unanimity, in the
April 9, 1992

House. That will be the way it will be proceeded with when it is appropriate.
I wish the hon. member was so enthusiastic about understanding other pieces of legislation we brought forward and so willing to discuss a way of accommodating these other pieces of legislation.

Mr. Speaker, I rise on the same topic. I do not think the government House leader is aware that the Chief Electoral Officer was in front of the House management committee today. I asked him specific questions with regard to the Elections Act and whether or not it was applicable and useful in terms of a national referendum. We talked about a number of issues from enumeration to the revision process, to expenditure limits. The problem is that entire act is based on candidates and political parties throughout.
Without trying to put words in the mouth of the Chief Electoral Officer, I am sure when the minister checks with his own people who were at the meeting he will be informed that the Chief Electoral Officer made it very clear he could not operate on the basis of the present Elections Act.
I asked him questions with regard to the recommendations of the royal commission, and again he said they would not apply with regard to a referendum.
In addition, when the private member's bill was tabled in front of the special committee chaired by the chief government Whip, it was made very clear by members of the committee that there is no way we can really examine that legislation. Our workload is too heavy. Based on the priorities we have set, it would require a House order for us to look at that private member's bill or any other referendum legislation.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
We could debate this all afternoon. The fact of the matter is that if there is a plebiscite or a referendum the people eligible to vote will undoubtedly be the same as those who are eligible to vote in a general election.
The polling stations will likely be the same places they would be in an election. The officers required to monitor in terms of returning officers, et cetera, would undoubtedly be the same.
Business of the House
All those kinds of details, important details to be sure but details nevertheless, can and will be dealt with at the appropriate time.

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the leader of the government in the House of Commons. The standing committees of the House are now examining the Main Estimates, and a number of departments and agencies are appearing before the committees to explain their expenditures. It is all part of the democratic process referred to as scrutiny of public spending.
The Standing Committee on official languages which is a standing committee of the House of Commons, has not met since it was reorganized, which means since October 21 or 22 last year, when we elected a new chairman, the hon. member for Halton-Peel, and we have yet to examine the Estimates. The government House leader knows as well as I do that the Estimates must be reported back to the House by May 31. They will be deemed to have been examined, although that will not be the case.
I would appreciate it if the government House leader, who decides how the House operate, would exercise some pressure.-1 have already tried. I presented an S. O. 31 in the House and I made representations to the Prime Minister. I would like to ask the House leader whether he could perhaps call his Whip or call the chairman of the committee, the hon. member for Halton-Peel, and ask him to hold a committee meeting so that we can get down to the business of considering these Estimates.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
One of the first things the Prime Minister did upon election in 1984 was appoint the McGrath commission. It established much more independence and authority for committees to act, and committees are masters of their own fate.
I hear the representation of the hon. member and I will certainly communicate his representation.

Mr. Speaker, I have asked the House leader before in House business and it relates to the royal commission on electoral reform.

April 9, 1992
Business of the House
I gather from the letters the House leader, the Minister of National Revenue and the Minister of Finance have given to me on a particular matter which only affects independent members that there is no thought of changing the act now to address the discrimination against financing of independent members who cannot give the tax receipt whereas registered parties can.
If the minister is not going to reflect on that over the Easter break, then I would suggest that the only alternative left for an independent member to redress this wrong is to take court action, the same as the Reform Party has done under the broadcasting item of the elections act and have an injunction against all political donations until this matter is resolved.
I would like the House leader to address that and/or seriously think about it over the Easter break because that is certainly one option that one may be forced to take. Regardless of the timetable of the committee and the royal commission recommendations and a law to implement them, the reality is that even if that is done before the next election, it is very much unlikely to be done in this calendar year and another year will have gone by. I think I have been patient enough.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
The committee studying the Lortie commission recommendations which deal with financing among other things, as I understand it, is looking at acting as expeditiously as possible. I understand they have been sitting long hours and will be able to bring forward recommendations for a new act that might be implemented quickly before the next election.
I understand that one of the categories of change that is under consideration in that regard is the question of financing for candidates in political parties.
I think a representation to the committee would be appropriate and I think it would be considered.

Mr. Speaker, in response to the government House leader who said we could stand here and debate the issue of referendum for a long time, I wanted to note that the member for Churchill was in fact giving a report of what took place at
the House management committee meeting in a discussion with the chief electoral officer.
Based on the response of the government House leader, I think it is even more imperative that the government have its officials meet with the chief electoral officer and see just what is necessary because the government House leader obviously has not been advised of what took place.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
I appreciate the lecture from the hon. member which seems to be her habit. I am aware of what is going on.
As I indicated to the House leader of the Liberal Party, I do recognize that there needs to be two pieces of legislation, one dealing with effective adjustments and additions to the elections act to allow for the conducting of a plebiscite. The more important issue is what question in fact the plebiscite would be asking of Canadians.
I indicated to the House leader of the Liberal Party, perhaps the hon. member was not there when I mentioned this, that in fact those considerations are being borne in mind at the appropriate time.
If it is appropriate, legislation will be brought forward. Then she will have the opportunity at second reading, committee study and report stages to go through all of those wonderful details and make sure it is perfect.

Mr. Speaker, I rise on a point of order asking unanimous consent to revert to presenting reports from standing, special or legislative committees in order to present the report on private member's Bill C-328, sponsored by the hon. member for Ottawa West. I have consulted with all House leaders.
Agreed.

I think that it would be appropriate at this time while legislation is being reviewed for the administration of government workers that the government show its regard for its workers.
April 9, 1992
