speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: The hon. member for Port Moody-Coquitlam had 13 minutes remaining in debate, plus 10 minutes questions and comments. The hon. member for Port-Moody-Coquitlam.

Mr. Speaker, 13 minutes, that is pretty lucky. I will try to make it 12.
This bill is called the Contraventions Act. It is part of the government's so-called protection of society week. This is the successor to the government's law and order week that it had some time ago. As I said the other day, let us get some law and order, not law and ornaments. There are a lot of ornaments here, a lot of publicity hype and so on, but let me deal with the bill.
As I said before, the New Democratic Party will support the bill to get it into committee and get it through quickly, because it seems like a fairly straightforward bill.
Government Orders
Just to be reminded of what the bill does, I am reading from the government's press release. The government says: "The Contraventions Act provides for tickets to be issued when a person commits a minor offence under a federal act or regulation". We have traffic tickets in the provinces and we have tickets for minor offences against provincial acts and regulations. Apparently we have a more formal system in the federal area and so the government is bringing in a bill to change that.
The government says that examples of minor offences include picking flowers on federal property-obviously not for the last few months in Ottawa, but maybe in Vancouver at the airport-hunting without a valid licence, and failing to dump refuge in a proper container while on park lands.
As a matter of fact in the government's press release it does issue a number of minor regulatory offences where the act will apply. They are a little bit more than picking flowers on federal property.
The government lists Agriculture Canada, Atomic Energy Control Board-we might want to look closely at that, what it is going to mean, what kind of offences there-Canada Ports Corporation, Communications Canada, National Defence, and Environment Canada. We are going to want to look very closely there so that we are not making offences against the environment act and that we are not downgrading these offences. Canadians generally, in my view, want to see increased penalties for offences against the environment and a tougher regime. The government mentions Fisheries and Oceans Canada as well. These are a number of areas mentioned by the government in its press release.
I mentioned that there are provincial laws in which the provinces have already done this. When we examine this bill our committee should look at how it is functioning in the provinces. How are these ticket regimes working and how will it work in the federal area?
Someone was saying to me the other day: "I guess what this will mean is now we will really have to pay our parking tickets at the airport". Before, parking tickets could be ignored because it cost too much money to go before the courts, rather than just to have them paid by mail, as can be done under the provincial offences. Maybe the government will end up collecting some money.

April 9, 1992
Government Orders
The government says in its press release that this will not cost money. We want to have a look at that. We do not want to waste money. We want to make sure we are not wasting money and we want to maybe get some money for the government.
The government says in its press release that it wants to modernize the law. It introduced a number of pieces of legislation this week. This is justice week or protection of society week, if I can call it that. We have debated legislation on anti-terrorism, legislation on jury selection, this bill on contraventions, the rape shield legislation that we debated yesterday, and so on. I want to say to the government that if it wants to modernize the law do not get rid of the Law Reform Commission. This government is going to do that. That is what it said in the budget. The Law Reform Commission is gone.
It was the Law Reform Commission in 1976 that brought forward some of these ideas, specifically the idea of this bill. The Law Reform Commission does the forward-looking research, or at least it did, and then we see the bills coming to Parliament. We have this bill and the bill changing the insanity provisions.
The hon. member from Okanagan-Similkameen and I were both Crown counsel in British Columbia and we know what it is like to go to court on some of these issues. He knows and I think the House knows that if you want to modernize the law you do not get rid of the Law Reform Commission. People say: "Well, you will save $4 million". As I have just said, we want to save money but this is not a good way of saving money.
This government is adding $16 million to its budget for lawyers in the department and for the litigation budget. So, it gives money there. Of course, those lawyers are always on the side of the government. And it takes money away from the Law Reform Commission which is looking to the future in law reform.
Similarly, it pays $800,000 a year to clip the papers for the Prime Minister so he can read his good press at breakfast.
That is wrong. It is $869,000.

Oh, sorry. My friend tells me it is $869,000.1 missed $69,000. That money could be used in justice related matters, specifically to keep the Law Reform Commission.
If you want to modernize the law you make the law equal and you make access to the courts equal. You do not get rid of the Court Challenges Program.
The government got rid of the Court Challenges Program at $2.7 million a year and it cut off the right to access of many people to challenge. The disadvantaged groups, women's groups, poor groups and so on would never get to the highest court of the country. They did have that access through the Court Challenges Program. The law was changed and a better law was made for it. We passed some bills that were dealt with in this House as a result of some of those cases. As a matter of fact, we dealt with one this week on jury selection.
I want to read a letter that was written to the Minister of Justice by Timothy Findley. Timothy Findley is one of Canada's foremost authors. His stories are a treat to read. Many members of the House have read his books.
I will just read this letter because he writes English a lot better than I write it or speak it.
"Dear Minister, I am both saddened and surprised that in its attempts to reduce spending and the deficit our present government has announced that among its belt-tightening measures will be the abolition of the Court Challenges Program.
There is a goodly proportion of the electorate which believes, as I do, that it is our social programs which not only hold this country together, but which also give us a vital component of our identity in the face of growing pressures to Americanize Canada and the Court Challenges Program has been an important part of our social contract, offering as it has, financial aid to those who could not otherwise seek redress in the courts against government infringements of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
I therefore urge you to resist attempts to abolish this important program. There are many other more costly and less important expenditures which can be examined with an eye to reducing federal spending.
April 9, 1992

Sincerely yours, Timothy Findley."
I say to the government, if you make some money on this program in collecting these fines and making this a more efficient program then let us take the money and put it back into the Court Challenges Program. Cut that big litigation budget. Put some money in the Court Challenges Program and get the Law Reform Commission going again.
There are only two countries in the Commonwealth that do not have Law Reform Commissions. This is a crazy cut. It is a ridiculous cut and a mean cut.
I will finish with protection of society week. If you really want to tackle crime, I am for tackling crime. I want lawn order not lawn ornaments.
Let us tackle crime, because Canadians are concerned about the increased violence in our society. You get adequate gun control, good regulations on control of firearms. You do not wait until next January as the minister announced today; you get the regulations now. You do not wait until next January so the people can buy all these guns and get big clip sizes and put them in the guns and you cannot make a change when it comes to next January. That is what has to be done to tackle gun control. You need the political will there.
You also change our prisons from being just a revolving warehouse system for criminals. What you do is get some decent treatment programs. You should be prepared to look at a new juvenile act in which you can deal with the juveniles right there with good treatment facilities, short and sharp sentences to catch juveniles before they become criminals.
You look after victims. You do not ignore victims in the criminal justice system. You tell them what is going on. You tell them what happens to the cases and you deal with the particular crimes. These are the kinds of things you can do if you want a protection of society week, not just announcements or fairly minor bills like this bill. We need some real substance.
That is what Canadians want in dealing with law and order in this country. We will see how this bill goes in committee. We will let it go now, for our part.
The parliamentary secretary may have something to say. I hope he stands up in the House and announces
Government Orders
that we get the Law Reform Commission again and we get the Court Challenges Program again.
I hope he cuts back the litigation budget and all that waste in the department and in the Prime Minister's office, channels it for justice and getting real protection for Canadians because that is what Canadians want.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a real pleasure to follow my colleague from Port Moody-Coquitlam who in his own right was and still is a very distinguished member of the bar and has served in other capacities in other jurisdictions. He has distinguished himself quite well.
I want to ask my colleague who has far more experience than I in terms of the actual practice of law a question. He has made mention of the Law Reform Commission. It seems to me that this is an important vehicle for the Government of Canada to utilize not only for the purpose of reviewing existing laws, but also to looking to the future in a way which Canadians could be somewhat visionary in terms of what laws they would like to see in the future.
I would like to ask my colleague who has distinguished himself at the bar as I said earlier in my remarks, what does he conceive of the reasons why a government would want to abolish the Law Reform Commission when, on the other hand, the Minister of Justice parades herself across this country from capital city to capital city saying that we have to modernize the law?
It seems to me to be somewhat-I use a harsh word and I do not normally do that-hypocritical to say on the one hand modernize, but on the other hand, the thing which you need to modernize the law both from a substantive point of view and also from an educational point of view is the Law Reform Commission.
I am wondering what reasons the hon. member could give as to why the government would want to proceed in such a Draconian fashion.

Mr. Speaker, that is a good question. The government has proceeded in a Draconian fashion. It has cut off its nose to spite its face, as the old expression goes.
Why? I can only speculate. One reason may be that the Minister of Justice did not have much clout in the cabinet with respect to losing these particular areas from the Department of Justice. The other reason may be that it was intentional.

April 9, 1992
Government Orders
The Law Reform Commission gave a report before Christmas in which it talked about a role for aboriginal self-government in the justice system, a kind of separate justice system for aboriginal people since the system has clearly been failing aboriginal people. That was directly against what the minister believed in and bang, there goes the Law Reform Commission. Perhaps I am being too suspicious. Look at the Economic Council of Canada. It brought in a report on Quebec that the government did not like and bang, there goes the Economic Council of Canada. That will teach the council.
Look at the Court Challenges Program. They kind of made life uncomfortable for the government. They challenged a few of the government's laws and the Reform Party does not like them. Bang, they are gone.
These are harsh reactions, ideological reactions from a government that is adrift and is shell-shocked. The government gets lots of applause in this House. The Prime Minister may get lots of applause in this House, but he walks outside the door of this House and he gets booed and has no support. I think the government is reacting from a shell-shocked, bunker mentality.
I can tell the hon. member that the government has also tried to combine freedom of information and privacy together in one office. This means that in fact it is going to restrict freedom of information and argue the right to privacy instead. It has been doing that consistently, if we read articles by journalists who try to get information. One of the worst offenders is the Minister for International Trade.
It is part of a pattern: cut back on access to government, cut back in information, cut out independent bodies that may say something different from what you are saying, spend your money on your own lawyers, pad your own budgets for public relations, for polling, and so on, and never release them to the Canadian people.
That is all right. We only have about 500 days left, I can tell my friend, and it will all be over. That is about the maximum before the election will be held. We are now in the countdown and Canadians will be very pleased, but let us hope the government does not do too much more damage before that period is over.

Mr. Speaker, I want to congratulate my friend for
all the work he has done as justice critic for the New Democratic Party.
I want to make a comment with respect to the apparent paradox we have before us with the justice ministry on the one hand streamlining the system with a ticketing method that it should have done years and years ago, and on the other hand cutting back on the programs he has talked about. As a member of the British Columbia Bar Association, I find it totally backward for the government to cut out the Law Reform Commission and the Court Challenges Program.
The Court Challenges Program has been used by minority people, aboriginal people, women in need, disabled persons, pensioners, seniors, all those people who do not have the ability because of lack of funding to have their cases properly heard. Often we found that those programs or those challenges have been landmark cases that have been taken and paid for under the Court Challenges Program.
As one who has worked for many of those groups over a period time and has been in the court system in British Columbia, I find that to be a very regressive step on behalf of the government and a surprise.
My question concerns the regulation end of the ticketing process. I found the member's remarks rather interesting in referring to the press release. I know that in the provinces things like the Wildlife Act, the Motor Vehicle Act and many others are done through a ticketing system. On the one hand it provides persons, whether working men or women or business persons, with the ability to pay their penalty in court rather than agree that they are guilty and pay a penalty set out by regulation. On the other hand, if persons wish to dispute it they still have the ability to go into court, have their day in court, have a trial, and have the matter heard by a full court. I wonder if there is any indication from the government as to what its plans are with respect to regulation, how extensive the regulations will be and what areas, aside from the ones he has mentioned, or how extensive within these areas the government will be regulating and whether it will be setting out penalties within each one of these within the regulations themselves.
April 9, 1992

Mr. Speaker, I thank the hon. member for his comments.
It looks like there will be, on reading the material, a right to a trial if you want one or the ability to just pay your fine. The member is right. We have to look at the regulations. That is why I am a bit suspicious when I read the government's press release that says, you know, it is a picking of flowers on government property. I suspect it goes a lot further than that. There are a lot more offences than that.
We are going to see the regulations in the committee. That is what I understand. I wait to hear the parliamentary secretary speak on this. The government so far has not set it out. In the previous debate it just paid tribute to an hon. member who had brought a case about boat regulations years ago. That was nice, but we would like to hear from the government.
We are going to push in committee to get those regulations, to have a look at them. We do not want, I think what the member is saying, the government to start legislating quasi-criminal law by regulation. It becomes too easy to do and it does not have enough public scrutiny.
I want to end with this. The Law Reform Commission came up with this idea in 1976. You are right. It has been going on a long time. What did the government do? It brings it in and then abolishes the Law Reform Commission. That is rather ironic, is it not?

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, if the parliamentary secretary wishes to enter the debate, I would gladly consent to allowing him to go before me if that is his wish.
I will not be all that long in my intervention. I just want at the outset on behalf of my party to congratulate my colleague from Cape Breton-The Sydneys who has done a superb job in regard to Bill C-46 as well as a host of other legislation which has come before the House. I listened quite attentively to what my colleague said with regard to this particular bill and, more important, with the whole issue of justice and the administration of justice in this country.
Government Orders
I asked on an earlier occasion my colleague from Port Moody-Coquitlam about the benefits of the Law Reform Commission. I must say that I would have to concur with what he has said. When one looks at this bill and its attempt to streamline certain things, one has to take into consideration a number of actions of the Government of Canada, particularly as of late.
We have another bill before us, Bill C-63. It is linked with this one as well in terms of the abolition of the Law Reform Commission.
We also have other budgetary matters which are of particular concern to ordinary Canadians. I note in Hansard that my colleague from Cape Breton-The Sydneys, my colleague from Ottawa Vanier, my colleagues from the Hamilton area, as well as my colleagues in the New Democratic Party have stated repeatedly the Government of Canada's ill-advised action in terminating the Court Challenges Program.
I know the hon. member opposite who happens to be the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice. I cannot for the life of me understand how such an honourable individual can sit in this place and allow the government to gut the Court Challenges Program.
Those very distinguished and able litigators in the Department of Justice have had their budget increased from $73 million to $89.5 million. That is $16 million or a little bit more. That is a pretty sizeable chunk of money. That is so they can go court and advocate a particular cause which in numerous instances is in direct opposition to what an ordinary citizen would like to take before the courts. What has the Government of Canada done for those ordinary citizens? How are they going to receive the kind of legal expertise that they will need in order to argue their case before a judicial body?
Previously there was money, less than $2 million if you will, set aside for the Court Challenges Program. Now, the government in modernizing the law has gutted the Court Challenges Program, thereby denying ordinary citizens the opportunity to present their case with the support of legal, and I will use the word loosely, expert counsel on particular issues of the day. On the other hand, the parliamentary secretary and his cronies have awarded themselves a $16 million increase for the

April 9, 1992
Government Orders
litigation dossier in the Department of Justice. If there was ever a demonstrable act of hypocrisy, that is it.
I do not wish to impute motive because that would be unparliamentary, but I suspect that you who sits in this chair and is the arbitrator of debate in this House, and known as a reasonable and prudent individual, would probably have many constituents who would look upon this example-on the one hand, $89.5 million for the litigation dossier in the Department of Justice and absolutely nothing under the Court Challenges Program-as being somewhat unfair.
I bet I could find individuals in my constituency who, if I told them that $89.5 million has been set aside for the government to argue its case and nothing has been given under the Court Challenges Program by the Government of Canada, would say that is unfair.
I could name constituents who would think that that would be unfair. I could name members of my own legal community. I could name distinguished legal counsel whom I know in Halifax. Elvin MacNeil for instance, might be of some interest to the parliamentary secretary across the way. What is even more frightful than this demonstrable act of unfairness and of hypocrisy by the Government of Canada is that the parliamentary secretary supports this.
I find that unbelievable. I would think that the people in Niagara Falls would be very, very disgusted to learn that their representative, who is supposed to represent all of the people and not just a click of people, is supporting a measure which would be so unfair.
That is the first point. The second point is in reference to the question on the Law Reform Commission.
I am not an individual who has years of experience at the bar, as my colleague from Cape Breton-The Sydneys, who in an earlier life, like my colleague from the New Democratic Party, distinguished himself at the bar, practised law and practised extensively corporate law, I might add, both in terms of the Cape Breton Development Corporation and the Sydney Steel Corporation. But it would seem to me that if one is modernizing the law, you do not gut or throw into the scrap heap the Law Reform Commission, which is the tool that can assist and facilitate the modernization of the law.
If we are going to ask the Department of Justice to do all the modernization of the law, I am afraid of what we
will get. No deference to those officials within the department, but they have their political masters who they are accountable to. Under the Law Reform Commission they had opportunities whereby they could reach out and get into different areas of the law, make recommendations, do examinations of existing studies, look to other jurisdictions, whether it be on a provincial basis or indeed internationally. Now we have forfeited the opportunity for the Law Reform Commission to do that because we have sacked the Law Reform Commission.
I find that to be extremely unfair and inappropriate for the Government of Canada to pursue. The Parliamentary Secretary will rise to close off this debate in a few moments. Notwithstanding the comments that I have of the public policy, I acknowledge that the parliamentary secretary in his own right is an able practitioner of the law. I wonder if the Minister of Justice has flown across this great country and whether she has touched base with the provincial Attorneys General across this country. I wonder if it has been an item at the various conferences of the provincial Attorneys General and whether they and the working committee of the deputy ministers of provincial Attorneys General have agreed that the Law Reform Commission is a waste of time.
I would venture to say, and I hope the hon. parliamentary secretary can prove me wrong, that they were not even consulted, that they had absolutely no say in terms of the termination of the Law Reform Commission. The hon. member opposite may shake his head and say that, technically, legally, the Government of Canada which will decide on whether the Law Reform Commission stays in existence or not. That is true, but the fact of the matter is that it has consequential effects and great impact on provincial jurisdictions in this country.
If we are looking at the country as a whole, as I am sure the hon. member and others in this Chamber do, one can see the rationale behind the Law Reform Commission.
I speak of the Law Reform Commission but I wish to state up front that I do not do so under a conflict of interest. I am a member of the bar as well, but I am not attempting to obtain some sort of position on the Law Reform Commission of Canada. I want to make that clear. But if you are going to modernize the law, and have individuals come to the commission to study the
April 9, 1992

issues which are of great importance, I think you still need a Law Reform Commission.
In an earlier day in a previous jurisdiction, I served with one of Nova Scotia's most renowned politicians who was an Attorney General himself, the late Judge Allan E. Sullivan. When it came to the Law Reform Commission, I can recall at previous meetings of the Minister of Justice and her provincial colleagues, the provincial Attorneys General, as well as the deputy ministers of Attorneys General, the importance they gave to the Law Reform Commission and, more important, the kinds of subject matter that the Law Reform Commission would study because provincial jurisdictions had neither the time nor the human resources in which to pursue that kind of examination.
I hope in the attempt to modernize the law, the parliamentary secretary and government will not bastardize the process in terms of eliminating the Law Reform Commission.
There are other issues which I wish to address. I will leave it at that because I know we are interested in hearing from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice. I hope that during his interventions, the hon. member will avail himself of the opportunity to explain to Canadians the unfairness of doing away with the Court Challenges Program while at the same time sucking $16 million into the litigation dossier of the Department of Justice. If he would explain the rationale for the gutting and the throwing to the scrap heap the Law Reform Commission, when at the same time, the minister parades across this country, into each and every capital and before every bar society in Canada, talking about the modernization of law. One of the most effective tools in modernizing the law, the Law Reform Commission, it has done away with. I wait eagerly to hear the comments from my colleague opposite who no doubt will want to provide the kind of information that members on this side of the House will need in order to pursue the debate in much greater detail than we have up to date.

speakeroldname: Mr. Rob Nicholson (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to talk about changes to the Contraventions Act, Bill C-46.
I along with other colleagues who spoke earlier on this want to congratulate my colleague, the member for Parry Sound-Muskoka. He is a very effective private mem-
Govemment Orders
ber, as you know, Mr. Speaker. He has had considerable influence and I would suggest considerable success in this House.
I remember when the President of the United States and the Prime Minister of Canada signed the acid rain agreement. Both the President of the United States and the Prime Minister made special mention of his work in the area of acid rain and his fight during his years in Parliament to see progress made on that. I think it was very fitting that both the President and the Prime Minister singled him out in that regard.
It was appropriate as well to have members of this House single him out again with respect to the bill that is before the House. The ticketing scheme proposed in this bill is one that is of particular concern to him and to other members who have recreational waterways and lakes within their ridings. I guess this is where, among other things, I would differ from the member of the New Democratic Party who spoke. He called this a minor bill and commented that this was law and ornaments week and why are we not bringing in important legislation, and all that. I guess it depends on if you are affected by something.
For my colleague, the hon. member for Parry Sound- Muskoka, tourism and the reasonable enjoyment of nature, the lakes, the forests in that particular area, is of concern to him. Tourism is a major concern in his riding.
I can tell the hon. member for Port Moody-Coquitlam, and I will tell all members of the House, this is not a minor piece of legislation for individuals who are affected by this. This is a good piece of legislation. I look forward to having it moved through the House and into committee where we can talk about it.
I tell the hon. member who thinks this is a minor piece of legislation that this is something that provincial and territorial colleagues of the Minister of Justice have been pressing for, for some time. It provides an alternative to the criminal court system, a system when taken up with minor matters, to which this bill addresses itself, can be both costly and inefficient.
On another day and in another debate, Mr. Speaker, you will hear members in this House decry the crowding of Canada's court system. You have heard that cry many times: the courts are too crowded; governments should do something about it. This is a very constructive piece of legislation.

April 9, 1992
Government Orders
Our provincial counterparts, all those involved with court systems in Canada, welcome this piece of legislation. Why? Because it provides an alternative to individuals who want to plead guilty to minor regulatory infractions. It provides them with a way to do that, so that they do not have to go through the criminal court process and clog up the courts, take up the court's time for some individuals to say: "I have made a mistake. It is a minor mistake. I just want to pay the fine. How do I do it?" Now we have established a regime to do that.
I can tell members of the House that those individuals for whom the overcrowding of Canada's court system is a problem, and it is an acknowledged problem, will welcome this. They will say that this is a step in the right direction.
I say to my colleagues in the Liberal Party who have said the Law Reform Commission came up with this in 1976, for heaven's sake, why did they not do it? Why did they not listen? What took them eight years? People are pretty generous with criticism around here.
I give credit to the Minister of Justice. She did not just think tough about this, she actually did something about it. She did something constructive. She heard comments from the member for Parry Sound-Muskoka. She consulted with her provincial counterparts. She consulted with other members of the House and has brought this forward.
I know it is a step in the right direction. It provides for three main objectives, the decriminalization of minor federal regulatory offences, the removal of uncontested cases from the courts: and the improved enforcement of fines. Who can argue with that?
It was asked in Parliament this afternoon: to whom and how does this apply? Well, I can tell the hon. member for Port Moody-Coquitlam that there are 12 different departments that are going to be a part of the initial phase. Each of the participants has chosen to have minor infractions within their department or jurisdiction included within the schedule of offences. I think it should be noted, and noted very clearly, this legislation does not
create any new offences, but rather provides a new, simplified procedure for the enforcement of existing minor offences.
In answer to the question the hon. member raised in his remarks, a list of those offences is available. They have been provided to the assistants to the critics of the other two political parties. We will have them in committee.
If members want to know exactly what we are talking about when we move this into committee, we can have a look at it. It will be right there to be seen so there is no mystery about what we are doing. I would even suggest there is no controversy about what we are doing. This was unanimously agreed to by people who want to unclog our courts and have a better more efficient way of handling minor offences.
One of the important things for me to do in this debate is to bring to the attention of the House the wishes of the Governor General with respect to this. Therefore I would like to bring to the attention of the House that clause 66 of the bill would abolish the right of the Crown to refuse to issue a passport or to revoke it as a consequence of a charge or conviction under the Contraventions Act.
This clause, which is a consequence of decriminalization of designated regulatory offences would affect Her Majesty's prerogatives.
His Excellency, the Governor General, has been informed of the purport of this bill and has given his consent as far as Her Majesty's prerogatives are affected to the consideration by Parliament of the bill, that Parliament may do therein as it thinks fit.
Let me conclude my remarks by saying a number of things. We have heard the member for Port Moody-Coquitlam asking why are we bringing in minor bills.
This has been a sterling week for people who want to see important legislation brought before Parliament. There is a tendency in this House, if something is not today, then we can forget about it and speak in a vacuum. However, in public security week, we have brought forward justice initiatives.
April 9, 1992

I believe it was unanimously concluded in this House and by every speaker that the rape shield bill that was brought before Parliament for second reading is major legislation. It is a major accomplishment that the Minister of Justice has brought this in. It was fine to acknowledge it yesterday, but it can be acknowledged today; it is very important.
It goes along with a whole host of legislation that has been brought in, some of it passed, some of it sent to committee. It will be interesting when the Minister of Justice appears before the Standing Committee on Justice.
I remember last year the member for Port Moody- Coquitlam said to the minister: "Well, you have not passed any bills. What bills have you done?" She has lots to talk about this year. I hope she gets the same question and she can tell all the great things that this Minister of Justice has done for Canada, the measures that have been brought before this Parliament, including the initiative of yesterday. That is a very important initiative.
I do not want to confine it to that. Members can move just the day before that when we were talking about the extradition bill which, as you know, was in the report and third reading stage. Again, it is major legislation. The hon. member for the Liberal Party says: "How will the people of Niagara Falls view this and other legislation that we have brought in?" I think they will view it very favourably. When I get the opportunity to tell them, as I mentioned two days ago, that the existing law gives them more rights of appeal if they are a fugitive fighting extradition than if they are charged with a criminal offence in Canada.
Who thinks that is a good idea? I told Parliament a couple of days ago that we are changing that. We are streamlining the process. That is not minor. That is something that all parliamentarians can and should applaud.
I hope this moves quickly through the House. I know some hon. members would like to see this in place as quickly as possible because of the benefits. I look forward to participating at the committee stage on this because this is an improvement. This is something that was talked about by the previous administration I know for eight
Government Orders
years, but it is something that the present Minister of Justice has done something about.

Mr. Speaker, first of all I want to make it very clear to the member that I, as a member of the New Democratic Party, and I believe our justice critic, has made it clear that the initiative set out in Bill C-46 is an initiative that has been long overdue.
The government has had some seven and a half years to bring it in. We are very interested in ensuring that it progress fairly rapidly and reasonably for a number of the reasons set out by the parliamentary secretary, not the least of which is tire convenience to the members of the public.
However, having said that, I think it is essential. I am pleased to see that the parliamentary secretary has indicated that the regulations will be tabled or shown ahead of time to the committee so that it has the opportunity of seeing exactly which areas will be governed by Bill C-46. That is very important, not only to us as parliamentarians but for the court system, for lawyers and for the public in general.
One of the things I noticed in listening intently to the member's comments in the defence of his Minister of Justice was all that has been done over the past week in particular in justice and certainly over the last year. When he talks about these things being done, the absence of one comment stands out. It has been pointed out by the justice critic for the New Democratic Party as well as the Whip for the Liberal Party concerning the abolition of a Law Reform Commission and the abolition of the Court Challenges Program.
As we tiy to get the system more streamlined and fairer for everybody, at the same time I put to the parliamentary secretary that the government seems to be backing off on two programs that have been very essential in the growth of the justice system and justice within Canada.
I turn particularly to the Canadian Bar Association's press release of February 28 and its comments in which it says that the CBA president also noted that the work of the commission-referring to the Law Reform Commission-has enjoyed considerable success.

April 9, 1992
Government Orders
"Its reports have been extensively cited by courts both inside and outside Canada, including the Supreme Court of Canada. Many of its recommendations have been implemented through both administrative and legislative action. CBA particularly regrets that a number of much needed projects which are already well advanced such as a new Criminal Code to replace the present 100-year old law will almost certainly never be completed".
That release from the Canadian Bar Association points out the folly of the policy of doing away with the Law Reform Commission. It points out the folly of where this government has gone.
The Criminal Code governs all of us. It is one of the few codes and laws of which all the people in Canada are well aware. It needs revamping. There are certainly people in our party who are looking at that. There is a committee of the House that is looking at it, but the Law Reform Commission has proven itself to be non-partisan. It looks in all areas. It has excellent people in it. I asked the Parliamentary Secretary to explain the shortsightedness of doing away with the Law Reform Commission. It has more than proven its worth for the small amount of money paid out over the years. The reform commission has proven its value to Canadian society. Why did they do away with it in the last budget?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, let me take one of the comments the member made towards the end, and I will work my way back to talk a little bit about the Law Reform Commission.
I disagree with the hon. member's comments concerning draft revisions to the Criminal Code. I know the hon. member for Lethbridge is very involved with this as a member of a subcommittee of the Standing Committee of Justice and the Solicitor General.
It is a huge undertaking, there is no question about that. Our present Criminal Code is approximately 100 years old. It was adapted almost in total from the British Criminal Code in force at the time. It is an enormous undertaking. If we just change one section of the Criminal Code, we as parliamentarians scrutinize it very carefully, as we should.
I do not share the member's pessimistic views about that. I put my confidence and trust in the member for Lethbridge who has undertaken this task. I believe he will see it through to a successful conclusion.
Let me talk in general terms about the comments of the hon. member about the Law Reform Commission being a good idea. I make no bones about it at all. The Law Reform Commission has done very good work in many pieces of legislation. I have been involved with 22 pieces of justice legislation, and I think it has done good work.
I guess I disagree with the NDP that any time you have a good idea it must continue and funding must not only be sustained at present levels, but increased.
I happen to believe there are outstanding researchers within the Department of Justice. At one time I was working on the young offenders bill, and wanted to mention to the members of the committee and the House the outstanding job I believed was done by the officials within the Department of Justice. Somebody said to me: "Well, you do not really do that. I guess we sort of pretend that we politicians do everything. That we come up with all good ideas. I just happened to write the changes to the Contraventions Act last week and I am presenting it to Parliament". Well, that is nonsense.
The research that goes on within the Department of Justice is outstanding in this particular area and in all areas in the justice field. I have complete confidence it will continue to bring forward the legislation we are discussing here today, legislation like the Young Offenders Act, the Rape Shield Act, changes to the Young Offenders Act, changes to the Extradition Act, all these things that have been developed within the Department of Justice. Of course it will continue to get good advice from people because it seeks out good advice. It contacts groups and individuals who are experts from across the country. It can and will continue to do an outstanding job of researching and developing legislation. I have complete confidence in that and so should the hon. member.

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise today to speak to Bill C-56, an act that purports to control program spending in the future.
The Conservative government members, with this act, would have us believe they are the only ones who understand spending controls and budget deficits.
I would like to make it perfectly clear that all of us on this side of the House as well as on that side of the
Government Orders
House are very much aware of the serious financial difficulties faced by this country and the government of this country. That does not mean we believe it knows how to control these difficulties.
The government would have us believe program spending is the reason we are facing these huge deficits. Although program spending has been a culprit, it is certainly not the biggest one. A lot of it has to do with the extremely high rates of interest we have been forced to endure by this government's very tight fiscal and monetary policy, especially over the last few years.
There is absolutely no doubt in my mind that if we had lower interest rates sooner, we might have had less difficulty and there would be more jobs now in this country.
The Conservative government, by this bill, seeks to impose its own agenda on the future governments of this country. That speaks very loudly to the fact this government realizes it will not be here after the next election. To be very honest, most Canadians are very anxious to have this happen and the sooner the better. There is absolutely no doubt in most minds across this country this country will be far better off without this Conservative government. Many of the woes we are facing now have a lot to do with the way this government has managed this economy.
Has anyone ever thought of what the supremacy of Parliament means? It means the government that is elected takes responsibility for its actions.
Yesterday I stood in this House and spoke to Bill C-49, a bill concerning the rape shield law. This particular bill would make everyone take responsibility for her or his actions.
This government has to take responsibility for its actions now. Why is it trying to impose its failed agenda? Just ask around. It has failed and failed miserably and is now trying to impose it on the future generations of this country.
I want this government to take responsibility for its actions now.
It would seek to impose restraints on program spending in its august position of ultra knowledge. We all know its predictions are worth absolutely nothing. It has never been able to come out right on anything it has predicted for this economy.

April 9, 1992
Government Orders
Now, after the benefit of this knowledge of the past which was non-existent, it is predicting program spending should be 3.3 per cent this year. It should be that amount, and that amount. Mind you, it will not include so-called self-financing programs, including unemployment insurance.
What happens if we are forced to pay more in unemployment insurance claims because of high unemployment? What happens then? Who foots the bill?
This is just a sham. It is a political shenanigan and there is absolutely no other way to look at it. I will tell you right now this government does not know how to control its own house and its own expenditures. There are some very glaring examples of it right now, starting with today.
Today I received this very beautiful book in my office. It is called "The State of Canada's Environment". I guess the costs for this were borne under Canada's green plan. Now we all know that Canada's green plan has to do with protecting our environment. This is a veiy beautiful book, but how is it going to help our industries become less polluting? It is absolutely beautiful reading, but it is also a very costly piece of literature. I have not had a chance to read it. I have just received it. I am sure many people will enjoy it, but will it help us control environmental pollution or will it just cause more pollution and excessive waste?
I leave the question to you and the people of Canada. In my thinking, the only way to control the environment and pollution is to actually bring in pollution abatement programs, not print fancy books.
That was a glaring example just today. How many millions have been spent? I do not know but I am about to find out.
Other glaring examples are the government's fantastic advertising campaigns. It certainly knows how to promote and advertise. You turn on the television set and hear about the wonderful Beaudoin-Dobbie report. Then the Prime Minister stands up in the House of Commons and says that is not really the government's policy. Well, if it is not really its policy then why are we advertising this report?
It is another example of one part of the government saying one thing while another part says something else.
Just recently there was a poll indicating that 66 per cent of Canadians believe that the free trade agreement was bad for us, that it did us absolutely no good, and that as a matter of fact it caused us a lot more pain than gain.
What is this government's answer to Canadians? Is it in programs to help the unemployed? No. There is a lot of nice talk but there is not a lot of nice action. There are no additional programs of retraining for our unemployed Canadians, but there is another advertising program. We are going to make all those unemployed Canadians feel good by spending money to tell them how great the free trade agreement was for some small number of companies. I am very happy that it has been good for some, but I certainly do not know of very many.
Spending those millions, and they are always millions, on advertising to convince Canadians of something that is at best shady, at best, a total waste of money. What this government is actually doing is using taxpayers' money in a pre-election advertising spree to try to promote itself as the saviour of our country.
Is that the way to spend money? In my way when you have no money you cut the frills and you quit the b.s. That is what this is all about. This is b.s.
I am going to give another very glaring example. This is all within one week. We do not have to read a lot of papers. We do not have to sit back for hours and do a lot of research. It is just all there for the taking, all the examples of the absolute waste and how this government says one thing and does another.
It relates to the depots under national defence. There was an announcement by the Minister of National Defence that he would spend $100 million building a depot in Montreal for national defence. I have no qualms with that. Montreal certainly needs job creation. But what it says to me is that they are not really doing what they say they are doing. They are saying one thing and doing another.
There have been many studies on these depots. In 1987 the then Minister of National Defence, who is now Minister of Communications, promised $100 million for the rebuilding of or a new depot in Moncton. The next Minister of National Defence, I guess a year or two later,
April 9, 1992

the present Minister of Agriculture, confirmed that decision. As well the now Minister of National Defence confirmed that decision.
The department went out and got 20 private sector proposals to build this new facility. It looked as if this particular proposal would cost less than $100 million. Actually the new proposals came in at around $70 million. Many of these groups spent a lot of money preparing these proposals.
During the last budget deliberations the Minister of National Defence cancelled the depot saying there was no money. It was difficult for the people of Moncton to accept that there was no money, but they knew it. We have all faced it and we all have to take some difficult decisions. They were prepared to accept that decision because there was no money. Three weeks later-not three years, not three months, but three weeks later- the Minister of National Defence announced that they were going to build a new facility and that they were going to build it in Montreal at a cost of $100 million. If we look at any reports or any of the studies that were done comparing which facilities would be most cost effective, Montreal was the least cost effective of all of them.

Some 450 people in Moncton. It is nice the government is going to create jobs in Montreal. I have no objections, but if it wants to create jobs in Montreal, why does it pit one region against the other? Why does it go against its own proposals of controlling spending? Why?
I remember at the end of the gulf war there was to be a peace dividend for the people of Canada. Where is that peace dividend? I have never seen anyone like this group opposite able to say "oh, by the way, we are decreasing expenditures" when all the time all they are decreasing is the amount of increase. When we look at the national defence budget that is where we really see it. We are playing little games, little boys' games, I must say.
When I look at some of the things that are happening I am not convinced we have to give out a $1 billion contract to build new helicopters for the military. I am not convinced of that. Maybe it is the right decision, but there are many, many places those dollars would be very beneficial.
Before the Conservatives try to foster their ideas I am going to be very happy not only to take responsibility for my future actions when we form the next government but also willing to assume the disaster they are going to leave us. That is what they are doing. It is not going to be easy, but I personally will never make these kinds of stupid promises that I cannot keep.
When we talk of cutting expenses we have to talk seriously. We cannot take from one pocket and put it in the other. This bill says program spending is going to be capped. Fine, fine. They pick a number out of the hat: 3 per cent. Why 3 per cent? Why not 1 per cent? Why not an increase? Why not a decrease? There are no explanations.
Why would they not control, on the other hand, the one sector that they are not controlling, that is the tax expenditure? This bill controls program expenditure, but it does not prevent any government from going out and giving its friends a huge tax break. That is not going to help the deficit. This does nothing to control that kind of thing, absolutely nothing. It does not include servicing the debt.

Government Orders
Have you ever heard of any business or any household that does not take into consideration all of its expenses when it budgets? Have you ever heard of anyone doing that? When we are looking at the money you bring in, do you turn around and say: "My mortgage payment does not count. I am going to put it aside over there and I am just going to spend on groceries and heating. My mortgage is separate?"
I will have you know, if your mortgage rate goes up you have to get the money from somewhere. You had better include it in your over-all budget or you are going to be in even bigger trouble. This does not do that. It does not. It has all kinds of loopholes, but basically it is a total and complete sham. It is this government trying to go to the Canadian people to tell them: "See how great we are".
One of my colleagues and the ex-chairman of the finance committee said to me: "What a funny bill. It is a got-ya bill. If you vote against it, it means that you are against controlling expenditures, so we have got ya".
That is not the way that I want to run this country. That is not the kind of legislation that we should be discussing in this House. It debases each and every one of us.
This is not a time to be playing political games and this is a political game from beginning to end. It is very much the time for all of us to sit down and start being honest with Canadians. There is no doubt in my mind that we can certainly run things better than what has been done in the past and we can certainly look after the people of Canada.
That is what we have to look at. It is fine to go on and rant and rave, but we have these glaring examples of absolute disregard for spending. There are many more. I just raised three or four of them I have become privy to in the last week.
This bill also says that in any one year the Minister of Finance can say that he will overspend the program limits. He has to state it. Then he has to tell the House of Commons how he will recoup that in the next two years.
What happens if, for instance, in 1993 when this government is facing an election it stands up and says: "All right, this year we are going to spend x dollars more than what this bill says and we will recoup it in the two
years following", knowing full well that it is not going to have to take responsibility for it"?
What kind of nonsense is that? I ask because I am absolutely disillusioned that what I thought were responsible people are trying to pull this kind of wool. I just become so incensed that people who purport to know how to run finances would try to limit and to fool the people of Canada in that way.
Can we imagine that? There is no doubt in my mind that that is all this is. There are many aspects of it that are uncontrolled. For instance, what happens if a government does not recoup in the following two years? What happens then? Who does what?
The Auditor General puts out a nice report and says: "You have been bad. You have not recouped the amount of money". Who elects the people sitting in this House? It is not the Auditor General. He reports to the people. The only real power remains with the people. Therefore, any government has to answer to the people, as this one will very shortly, within the next year. It will also get a very strong message within the next year. It is already getting it. It chooses not to hear it, but it is getting it.
It has to do with the supremacy of Parliament. Parliament makes its own decisions. What would happen if we as a government, or you as a government, decided to trade tax points for revenues or decided, for instance, that you would turn a program over to the provincial level. We are discussing that right now in the constitutional debate. If we were to turn over a program to another level and in return we would allow them more tax room, what would this bill do? It would still say that program spending should stay at that level. Program spending should not stay at that level if we turn a program over to another level of government. It should not.
Sound decisions based on what is happening on the day and in the year is what is needed and not in some sanctimonious, pious way, and I have to watch my next statement, what this group is trying to perpetrate on Canadians across this country. The record of this government speaks for itself, and it is not a good record. Until this government starts to do what it says it is going to do, it will continue to have no respect in the eyes of Canadians.
April 9, 1992

Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to speak on a bill which should be called the deficit increase bill because that is what we have in front of us. We have a bill which opens the door to increase the deficit as far and as completely as one wants to in this country.
We had thought when this piece of legislation first came before the House that it might have something to do with trying to control deficits, that it might have something to do with trying to make the government of this country pay some attention to the fact that we have a national debt of over $420 billion, that we in fact have in this country a government which has consistently missed its deficit reduction targets, a government which has consistently failed to bring the finances of this country into any kind of sense of balance, even during the good times that existed in the latter part of the 1980s.
We thought that this bill might possibly put some brakes on this government's habit of giving tax breaks to its friends and continuing to increase expenditure and driving up the deficit.
In fact, many witnesses came before us in committee. Those many witnesses convinced the finance committee, and the finance committee came back with a report to the House of Commons which said very clearly if you want to control the deficit, you have to control tax expenditures.
You cannot continue to make it possible for a government to come in on budget day and say: "Well, we are going to change something which in the past has been a program of direct grants to people. We are going to make it a program of tax credits to people".
That is a fascinating change, but what it does is increase the deficit and at the same time has the effect on paper of reducing the expenditures. Yes, it is true expenditures are reduced, but tax giveaways are increased. That is what this debate is about. It is about the fact that the finance committee of this House of Commons unanimously said to this government: "If you are going to be serious about this bill, you have to put some controls on tax expenditure". If you are going to be serious about this legislation, if you are going to be
Government Orders
serious about deficits in this country, you have to accept that you cannot simply hand away tax breaks to large corporations or to different groups within the country that shout and scream. You cannot come in as the government did just yesterday and say: "Yes, it is true that we had planned to increase taxes by $150 million on the tobacco companies in this country, but the tobacco companies have pressured us. They persuaded us and so we are going to get rid of that tax".
You cannot have a system where the government can get rid of taxes, hand out goodies to its friends, make new giveaways to target groups that it wants to support in the election campaign and then expect the deficit in this country to be controlled.
It is interesting that the Minister of Finance, when he first introduced this legislation last year, said: "You know, we have looked at the United States. We have seen that in the United States they have some expenditure control systems in effect which are aimed at reducing their deficit. We think we have to follow that route".
It is interesting. The finance committee went to the United States. We talked to American legislators. We talked about the congressional and White House budget staffs. They told us very clearly that at the heart of the American legislation was a system which said if you want to come in and give a whole new tax giveaway program to somebody, you have to pay for it. You have to pay for it either by increasing taxes or by reducing expenditures. Otherwise you get continued increases in the deficit.
The finance committee listened. The finance committee, which is made up of all three parties in this House, unanimously came to the conclusion that our deficit problems are so serious in this country at the federal level that we have to to something to control the deficit. They said if you are going to control the deficit, you have to include in this legislation something such as is in the American legislation, something that says if there is a new tax giveaway system, it has to be paid for. What is absolutely remarkable, what is incredible, coming from this government which says it is worried about the deficit, which stands up and preaches to other provinces in this country, to other governments in this country with respect to the deficit, despite that preaching about the evils of deficits, what we have in front of us is a bill to authorize the increase in deficits in Canada.

April 9, 1992
Government Orders
That is what this bill should be entitled. This bill has rejected the key recommendation which the finance committee unanimously made to the government. It has rejected the heart of the expenditure control system in the United States. It has rejected the idea that there has to be some kind of limitation on tax giveaways.
The tax giveaways will continue. We can look at some of these tax giveaways. We can look at, for instance, the $1 billion tax giveaway which exists in the form of the business entertainment tax deduction. Corporations can buy season tickets to Blue Jays baseball games. They can buy season tickets to Vancouver Canucks hockey games, if we ever have those in the future. Corporations can take clients to expensive dinners, to receptions, and they can get all of this deducted from the taxes that they have to pay to the Government of Canada. One billion dollars it costs us.
Let us talk about another tax giveaway. Over $3 billion is given away by this government in the capital gains tax exemption of $100,000. This is not the usual tax giveaway for people who sell their principal residence. The capital gains tax on principal residence is something which all of us support. It is about seeing that people are decently housed.
Tax exemptions for small business of $500,000 we support because it helps small business. We support it for farmers up to $500,000. We are not talking about that. We are talking about the tax giveaway that lets people make money by speculating on the stock market and says those people do not have to pay a penny in tax.
That costs federal and provincial governments in this country $3 billion each year. Over 60 per cent of that tax giveaway goes to people whose individual income is over $100,000 per year. Over one-quarter of that tax benefit goes to people whose individual income is over $250,000 per year.
We are talking about massive tax giveaways that this government has put into effect. We are talking about, for instance, the tax giveaways that are being increased with respect to Registered Retirement Savings Plans in the increased limit for putting money into RRSPs, which is being put into effect each year, a policy that was started by the Liberal government, continued by the Conservative government. We are talking about the fast write-offs that exist for corporations in this country when they
make investments. All of these are at the very root of the massive public debt that we have in this country. They are responsible for the fact that the deficit in this coming fiscal year is going to be $3.5 billion higher than the government said it would be last year. They are at the root of the total fiscal irresponsibility which this government has stood for ever since 1984 and which the Liberal government stood for before that.
We are spending ourselves into an economic disaster, but the problem is not program spending. The problem is tax giveaways.
I moved an amendment in committee to try to put into this legislation the unanimous recommendation of the finance committee of this House. Believe it or not, this government of people supposedly concerned about the deficit voted against that amendment.
Not only has it brought in a bill which should be entitled how to increase the deficit in Canada, but it has refused to support opposition attempts to see to it that tax giveaways were attacked as they must be if we are going to get ourselves back to a position in this country where we will have some ability to shift expenditures as economic conditions change, where we have enough fiscal responsibility being demonstrated by government that interest rates will come down significantly.
This is not just a bill to increase the deficit in Canada. It is a bill to continue high interest rate policies in this country. In the face of this government's refusal to be responsible in its budgets, the Bank of Canada has pushed interest rates far higher than they have ever been in this country compared to the levels in the United States. This has hurt the economy. It has brought about a recession which has thrown 1.5 million people out of work.
This legislation is so profoundly irresponsible, so profoundly counter to the needs that this country has at the federal level to see some serious attempts to deal with our deficit problem that we can no longer support it.
I was one of those people who signed the unanimous finance committee report of this House saying that it made sense to have legislation like this, on condition that it controlled tax spending as well as program spending. This government has refused to bring such legislation before this House. It has instead brought legislation before us which is designed deliberately to increase the
April 9, 1992

deficit and that is something that we, at the federal level, will never support in 1992.
This is a bad bill and it should be defeated.
